Exercise Description: Lie on your back with a kettlebell in one hand, pressing it straight up over your shoulder with a locked-out elbow. Bend the same-side knee, keeping your foot flat on the floor while your opposite leg remains straight. Rotate your torso and hips by rolling onto your side, keeping your eyes on the kettlebell at all times. Hold the position for a moment, maintaining shoulder stability and core engagement, then return to the starting position with control.

Exercise Name: Incline Bench Side Lying Lat Raises - DB
Exercise Description: Lie on your side on an incline bench, holding a dumbbell in your top hand. Lift the weight out to the side, keeping a slight bend in your elbow. Lower under control and repeat.
Hold a towel or resistance band under your foot, gripping both ends with your hands. Perform a bicep curl against the resistance, keeping your elbows tucked. Lower under control and repeat.

Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Swing your arms back while bending your knees slightly, then explosively jump forward, maximising horizontal distance. Land softly on both feet and measure the jump.

Start with your feet shoulder-width apart, a slight bend in your knees and a forward lean with a straight back. Hold each dumbbell to your chest so that the end plates face toward the ground and the ceiling. Hold your elbows in to your sides and roll your shoulder blades back. Bring each dumbbell up
towards your shoulders in a circular butterfly motion while keeping each elbow firmly to your side. Lower back to the start position for the next rep.

Start with a crossover step, transitioning into an explosive sprint. Focus on a strong lateral push-off, ensuring a quick transition into acceleration. Keep your body low and drive forward aggressively.

Lie on your back with a foam roller or lacrosse ball positioned under your lower back just above the pelvis. Slowly shift your weight side to side, applying pressure to any tight areas. If using a lacrosse ball, target one side at a time by leaning slightly into the pressure and holding for a few seconds before moving to the next spot. Keep your breathing controlled and avoid excessive arching of the back.

Lie on your back with a foam roller positioned across your upper back (thoracic spine). Support your head with your hands or cross your arms over your chest. Engage your core and slowly extend your upper back over the roller, pausing at any tight spots. Use small, controlled movements to mobilise the thoracic spine, avoiding excessive movement through the lower back. To increase intensity, lift your hips slightly or perform the movement with arms overhead to target restrictions in shoulder mobility.

Hang from a pullup bar with a narrow grip (one hand’s space between each hand), facing away from your body. Pull
yourself upwards so that your chin reaches level with the bar, then slowly lower yourself down again. Keep your feet
off the ground at all times during sets.

Stand in a split stance with one foot forward and the other foot behind, holding the Viking press handle in front of your chest with both hands. Begin by lowering into a split squat, bending both knees until your back knee is just above the floor while keeping your chest upright. As you press through your front heel to return to the standing position, simultaneously press the Viking handle upwards and slightly forward, fully extending your arms. Bring the handle back to your chest as you lower into the next split squat. Ensure you maintain balance and stability throughout the movement by engaging your core.

Start in an athletic stance with your feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent and core engaged. Lean forward slightly, ensuring your weight is on the balls of your feet. Explosively push off the ground with maximum effort, driving your knees high and maintaining powerful arm swings. Keep your strides long but controlled, ensuring proper sprint mechanics – head neutral, shoulders relaxed and foot contacts landing under your centre of mass. Maintain full acceleration through the sprint distance, ensuring top-end speed is reached and held before decelerating gradually. Walk back to the start and take full recovery before repeating.

Position a barbell in a landmine attachment and stand  perpendicular to the bar. Grasp the end of the barbell with the inside hand on top and the outside hand underneath. Perform a deadlift, lifting the bar to waist height, then pivot on your back foot to rotate your torso as you press the bar diagonally upward in the direction of its base. In this process you can remove the inside hand as it is not used in the press. Lower the bar back to the start position with control.
Kneel on one knee with the other leg extended straight out to the side. Slowly push your hips back while keeping your back straight, then return to the start.

Mark out a 10-15m sprint lane. Start in an athletic stance and sprint forward at maximum effort. At the designated marker decelerate rapidly by lowering your hips and planting your feet in a stable position. Stop completely and "freeze" in a balanced stance for 2-3 seconds. Focus on controlling your momentum during the deceleration phase, keeping your chest upright and knees aligned over your toes.

Maintain the same upper body control as before, with extended arms throughout the rotation. This time however, shift your hips at the same time so that you finish in a fighter’s stance facing away
from the machine.
Stand on a raised surface with a barbell on your back, ensuring your heels are hanging off. Rise onto your toes and hold at the top position, maintaining tension in the calves. Lower under control.

Stand sideways to a cable machine or resistance band anchor, holding the handle or band at chest height with both hands. Press the handle straight out, keeping your core tight and avoiding rotation. From this extended position, lift the weight or band overhead, maintaining control and resisting the pull of the band. Lower back down under control before bringing your hands back to your chest.

Stand facing a landmine attachment with the bar held close to your chest. Shift your weight onto one leg and lower your body into a single-leg squat while simultaneously moving the other leg diagonally behind you, mimicking a skater’s motion. Keep your chest upright, core engaged, and knee aligned over the toes. Push through the working leg to return to standing, maintaining control and balance throughout.

Stand facing away from the throwing direction with an 8kg medicine ball held in both hands. Plant your feet shoulder-width apart. Squat slightly to generate power, then explosively drive through your legs and hips while throwing the ball overhead and backwards as far as possible. Use a strong upward and backward motion with your arms to maximise the throw distance. Maintain control of your body throughout the movement and ensure a safe area behind you for the throw.
Start in a tall kneeling position, holding dumbbells at shoulder height. Press the weights overhead, fully extending your arms without arching your lower back. Lower under control and repeat.

Strap into the rower and grasp the handle with both hands. Begin each stroke by pushing with the legs, then lean back slightly at the hips as you pull the handle to the lower ribs. Reverse the motion to return. Maintain a smooth, connected sequence with each stroke, and avoid over-relying on the arms. Full intensity and pace is expected during each set/cycle.

Stand lateral to the machine and grip a cable handle with the inside of your hand. Avoid leaning too far forward with this unilateral movement as stability may be compromised. Place your spare hand against your hip for stability. Pull your arm down in front of you forming an arc in front of your chest. Squeeze your chest at the end of the motion and return to the starting position. Ensure to keep your core engaged throughout the movement and breathe.

Anchor a resistance band at chest height and hold both ends in front of your body. Take a small step back to create tension. Set your elbows at 90° and rapidly pulse the hands forward in short explosive pushes while maintaining posture and shoulder control. The movement should be fast and reactive from the chest with minimal range. Stay tall and still through the torso, maintaining band tension at all times.

Start at the top of a moderate downhill slope, ensuring the incline is not too steep to maintain control. Begin sprinting gradually, allowing the natural slope to increase your speed while keeping your stride controlled and posture upright. Focus on quick, light foot contacts, minimising braking while maintaining an efficient forward lean. Avoid overstriding or allowing your feet to land too far in front of your body, as this can increase the risk of injury.

Sit on the floor with your upper back resting against a bench and a barbell or weight plate positioned over your hips. Drive through your heels, lifting your hips until your torso forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Hold this top position for three seconds, keeping your glutes engaged and core tight before lowering with control.

Lie on your back with one foot flat on the floor and the other leg extended straight. Push through the heel of your grounded foot, lifting your hips while keeping your extended leg in line with your torso. Hold briefly at the top, ensuring your glutes and hamstrings are engaged, then lower slowly.

Exercise Name: Ring Row to Reach (Heels on Floor)
Exercise Description: Set gymnastic rings at waist height and grip them while leaning back with your heels on the floor and body in a straight line. Pull your chest to the rings by driving your elbows back. At the top of the row, pause and extend both arms forward into a reach before returning to the rings. Lower yourself back under control to the start. Keep your core engaged and avoid sagging at the hips.
Wait for 30 minutes post-session then Ice / Game Ready the afflicted area for 10 minutes each hour for three hours.
Stand on the edge of a step with one foot off the ground. Slowly lower your free leg to the side, keeping it straight, then return under control. Focus on controlled movement and glute activation.

Stand tall and take a small step forward. With the front leg extended and heel on the ground, reach down with both hands to ‘scoop’ under the toes, keeping the back flat. Step through and repeat on the other leg. Maintain an upright posture between scoops and move with steady rhythm. The motion stretches the hamstrings dynamically with each step.

Stand in front of a box or bench. Step one foot onto the platform and drive your opposite knee upward explosively while maintaining balance. Return to the starting position with control and repeat on the same side before switching.
Stand tall with a dumbbell in each hand, pressing the weights overhead until arms are fully extended. Lower under control and repeat. Keep your core engaged throughout.

Exercise Name: Sprint to Deceleration to Back Pedal
Exercise Description: Start in a sprint-ready position, then accelerate forward for a short burst. As you reach top speed, quickly decelerate by lowering your centre of gravity, absorbing force through your quads and glutes. Immediately transition into a controlled backpedal, keeping your knees bent while maintaining control. Focus on efficient braking mechanics, smooth transitions and proper foot placement.
Perform quick, reactive hops, moving in a zigzag pattern while maintaining minimal ground contact time. Keep knees slightly bent and ensure smooth lateral transitions.

Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell held in front of your thighs. With a slight bend in the knees and a flat back, hinge at the hips to lower the bar slightly above the knees. From this position, extend powerfully through the hips, knees and ankles while pulling the bar upward with straight arms, leading with the elbows. Finish tall, then reset. Keep the bar close to the body and avoid excessive backward lean.
Perform a Nordic hamstring curl with a resistance band attached to provide assistance. Control the descent and ascent, focusing on maintaining tension throughout the movement.

Stand in a split stance with your back heel raised, keeping your torso upright and core engaged. Lower into a slight forward lean, loading the front leg before explosively driving the knee upwards in a powerful motion. Hold the top position momentarily before resetting. Maintain a smooth, controlled transition between loading and lifting, ensuring force is transferred efficiently.

Set cones up to denote defenders in a back line. Sprint across this line with a slight curve using one of the cones as a trigger to turn the corner and run in behind the defence. As you turn the corner, try to maintain a high pace while simultaneously dropping to tap the cone.

Lie face down on an incline bench, holding dumbbells in both hands. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, raise your arms out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower the weights under control before repeating.

Stand facing a wall for support, lift one knee outward at 90 degrees, and hold the position while engaging your glutes and core. Maintain balance and control without rotating your hips. Switch sides after completing reps.

Attach a resistance band to your feet and a low anchor point, then hang from a pull-up bar. Perform a single-leg marching motion, lifting your knee towards your chest, engaging your core throughout. The band provides resistance to improve strength and control.

Hold a bar at waist height, positioning your body underneath. Keep your legs extended and core engaged. Row your chest towards the bar, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower under control.
Traditional bounds into the air from one leg to the other; lifting one knee up to waist height while springing up off your opposite foot. Perform forwards, then right, then left.

Stand sideways to a wall and lean in towards it with one hand against it at enough of an angle such that you would fall over if the wall were not there. Powerfully swing your outside hip around to face in towards the wall, bringing your torso with it to finish facing the wall, and your knee high up to hip height. From this position, immediately double switch by driving the standing foot upwards and simultaneously dropping the high knee back down towards the ground, repeating the switch one more time to return to the original inside leg being the standing side to finish. Maintain low and aggressive acceleration mechanics. Reset to the start position after the double switch.
Stand tall and lift your right foot off the ground. Rotate your ankle in a slow, controlled circular motion. Perform clockwise and counterclockwise rotations.

Begin in a tall, upright stance. Drive one knee upwards to hip height while striking down with the opposite arm in a forceful motion. Alternate sides with quick, powerful movements, focusing on high knees, a strong vertical torso and active arm drive. Stay on the balls of your feet and minimise ground contact time. Each movement should be crisp and purposeful, simulating the timing and rhythm of top-end sprinting without covering distance.

Set the cables at chest height and stand in a staggered stance. Grip the handles and press them forward until your arms are extended in front of your chest. Pause briefly, then return under control to the start position. Keep your core braced and avoid flaring the ribs or leaning backward. The motion should come from the chest and shoulders while maintaining trunk stability.

Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg extended straight. Press through the heel of the bent leg to lift your hips while keeping the extended leg in line with your torso. Squeeze your glutes at the top, then lower under control before repeating.

Stand with a wide stance and toes slightly turned out, gripping the barbell inside your knees. Drive through your heels, keeping your chest lifted, and extend your hips and knees simultaneously to stand tall. Lower under control.

Lie flat on a bench, holding dumbbells above your chest with your palms facing forward. Lower the dumbbells slowly and under control until they are just above your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the weights back up explosively, ensuring full extension at the top.

Start in a split stance with 80% of your weight on the front leg. Sink slowly into the front leg to fully transfer your weight forward and then pausing with control. Push back into the start position with force using glute and hamstring drive. Keep the torso tall, hips loaded. Your weight stays forward throughout, but you are training yourself to use ground force to push your weight backwards.

Lie on your back with a stability ball pressed between your hands and knees. Extend one arm and the opposite leg while keeping the ball pressed with the other limbs. Return to the start and switch sides. Keep core engaged throughout.

Stand tall with your feet shoulder-width apart. Reach your arms straight up towards the ceiling, then lower into a deep squat while keeping your chest upright and arms overhead. Push through your heels to return to standing, maintaining an extended spine throughout the movement.

Start in a downward dog position, with your hips high and arms extended. Lower your chest down and forward, moving through a smooth, arcing motion, finishing in an upward dog position with your hips lowered and chest lifted. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position, maintaining fluid movement and core control throughout.

Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width. Shift your bodyweight into your right leg by bending the knee and sitting your hips back and down, keeping your left leg straight. Stay in that loaded position briefly. Then guide your body back toward the middle using the pressure from your right leg. Move with control. Let your left leg take the weight as you return. Repeat the same movement in the opposite direction. Focus on how you enter the loaded position and how you leave it. Each phase should be smooth, clear and grounded.

Start in a split stance with the Torsonator bar (or landmine) held at shoulder height, gripping it with both hands. Engage your core and keep your chest upright as you drop into a slight dip by bending both knees. Explosively extend your hips and drive the bar upward, simultaneously jumping into a deep split stance, landing with your front knee bent at 90 degrees and your back knee hovering just above the ground. Maintain stability, ensuring your hips stay square and the bar moves in a straight path. Hold briefly, then reset back to the starting position before repeating.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides with a firm grip. Walk forward slowly to cover the distance, then turn to repeat the opposite direction. Keep your shoulders back, chest up, and core engaged. Maintain a steady pace, ensuring your posture stays upright throughout the movement.

Position yourself on the leg press machine with your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. Ensure your lower
back and head are against the back pad. Release the safety levers and bend your knees to lower the platform, keeping
your feet flat. Drive through your heels to push the platform back to the starting position, fully extending your legs
without locking your knees.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart and hold a cable handle at shoulder-height while facing away from the machine. Drop into a half squat, then immediately drive outwards, pushing the cable out in front of you in a fast, explosive motion. Step one foot forward as you press, finishing in a staggered stance with your core braced and arms fully extended in front. Return the handle back to your shoulders with control.

Set two boxes up with one to two metres between them. Start atop the shorter box of the two (check the heights above). Step off this box to land on the ground below with a slight bend at the knee and sinking in towards a half-squat. From there, focus on jumping as high as possible to land on the taller box in front.

Hold one end of a battle rope in each hand with feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent. Generate rapid, alternating waves by lifting and lowering each hand in a fluid rhythm. Keep the core braced and avoid excessive upper body movement. Maintain continuous motion at full pace throughout the set, focusing on consistent wave size and speed.

Stand with your heels elevated on small weight plates or a wedge board  and your toes flat on the ground. Position your feet shoulder-width apart and keep your chest upright. Place the barbell across your shoulders behind the neck and lift into the starting position. Brace your core and initiate the squat by bending your knees and lowering your hips down and back. Focus on keeping your knees tracking over your toes and your heels rooted into the plates. Descend until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your midfoot and heels to return to standing. Maintain a neutral spine and avoid allowing your torso to collapse forward.

Exercise Name: Side-Lying Abductor Raises with Dumbbell Over Leg
Exercise Description: Lie on your side with your bottom leg extended straight and your top leg bent at the knee, with the foot placed flat in front of your lower thigh. Keep your core engaged and torso stable as you lift your bottom leg off the ground, squeezing your inner thigh at the top. Lower back down slowly and under control, avoiding any twisting of the hips.

Exercise Name: Sprint Arc with Midline Break Exit
Exercise Description: Set up an bending arc to follow with cones, e.g. sprinting onto and then along the defensive line. At any point along the straighter portion of this line, 90° turn in either direction imitating a run in behind or dropping to feet. Focus on good mechanics and applying a burst to break free in the new direction.

Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight to one side by bending the knee and keeping the opposite leg straight. Hold briefly, then switch sides. Keep your chest upright and core engaged.
Lie face down on a back extension machine or floor. Engage your glutes and lower back, lifting your torso upwards until aligned with your lower body. Lower under control before repeating.

Kneel on a soft surface with your feet anchored under a heavy object or held by a partner. Slowly lower your torso forward while keeping your hips extended, using your hamstrings to resist gravity. When you can no longer control the descent, catch yourself with your hands and push back to the start position.
Hold the TRX handles with an overhand grip, keeping your body in a straight line. Pull yourself up towards the handles, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower under control.

Stand tall holding a barbell at your thighs with a shoulder-width underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders without swinging or leaning back. Once the bar reaches chest level, rotate your grip as needed and press the bar overhead in one smooth motion. Lower the bar back to the chest and reverse curl back to the start. Keep elbows close and posture solid throughout.

Lie on your back holding a kettlebell or dumbbell in one hand with your arm fully extended above your shoulder. Bend the same-side knee, placing your foot flat on the ground while the other leg remains straight. Press through your heel and elbow, rolling onto your opposite forearm before transitioning onto your hand. Engage your core and glutes as you lift your hips high into a bridge position. From here, sweep your straight leg under your body into a half-kneeling position, keeping the weight locked overhead. Drive through your front foot to stand up tall, then reverse the movement back down to the starting position. Keep your eyes on the weight throughout to maintain balance and control.

Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell at chest height, keeping your elbows tucked in. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, then lower into a deep squat, ensuring your knees track in line with your toes. Keep your chest lifted and core engaged, then drive through your heels and midfoot to return to standing.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Perform a full squat, keeping the chest tall and heels grounded. As you drive up from the bottom of the squat, press both dumbbells overhead in one fluid motion. Lock out fully at the top, then lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat. Maintain a strong core and do not pause between squat and press phases.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand, hinge slightly at the hips, and raise your arms out to the sides with a slight bend in the elbows. Lower under control and repeat. Avoid excessive swinging.

Exercise Name: Standing Long Jump to Shooting Position
Exercise Description: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and arms extended behind you. Perform a maximal jump by swinging your arms forward and explosively pushing off both feet. Land softly on one foot with a bend at the knee, coordinating your body to retain balance while the non-standing leg extends back into a loaded up shooting position. Hold momentarily to establish control and alignment before resetting.

Starting from a box, step off to land on the ground with both feet at the same time. Your aim is to immediately leap back up vertically. When you land again, repeat the same fast vertical jump.
Repeat this one more time for a total of 3 vertical jumps before finishing with a controlled landing.
Stiffen the body with each leap. While you want to keep as much height vertically, it is most important to spend little time on the ground and allow the existing energy to contribute to height rather than trying to add more.

Start in a tall kneeling position with your hips fully extended and core engaged. Explosively drive through your hips, using your arms for momentum, to jump into a standing position with both feet landing firmly on the ground. Absorb the landing softly and reset before repeating.

Set up mini hurdles or cones spaced evenly in a straight line, typically 1.5 to 2 meters apart. Begin by sprinting through the wickets with an emphasis on high knee recovery and proper foot placement. Each step should be quick, controlled and directly under the hips, ensuring the foot lands beneath the body rather than reaching forward. Focus on tall posture, active arm drive and maintaining stiffness through the ankles and lower legs to generate efficient ground contact. Avoid excessive vertical movement and aim for a rhythmic, consistent stride pattern.

Step forward onto your heel, roll through your foot and push off with your toes. This engages the entire foot and improves ankle range of motion. Land on the other foot to continue the walking motion with the same process from heel through to toe.

Start on all fours, keeping your back neutral. Extend one leg straight back, engaging your glutes and hamstrings, then return under control before switching sides. Avoid excessive lower back movement.
Perform a Nordic hamstring curl, but place a box in front to tap at the bottom of the movement. Lower under control, tap the box lightly, then return to the start. Focus on eccentric control.

Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell or kettlebell overhead in one hand. Keeping your eyes on the weight, hinge at your hips and reach your opposite hand toward the inside of your shin or ankle while keeping your legs straight. Return to the starting position by driving through your hips and engaging your core.
Perform the Prone Jack Knife, but with one leg remaining extended while the other drives towards the chest. Alternate sides. Focus on core and hip stability.

Begin in a split stance with one foot forward and the other behind, both feet flat on the ground. Shift your weight slightly forward and reach both arms out in front of you, lowering your chest slightly without collapsing. Hold the position briefly, then return to upright. Keep your front knee aligned over the foot and avoid excessive backward lean. Focus on hip stability and maintaining balance throughout.

Stand tall with arms bent at 90 degrees. Begin sprinting on the spot by driving the knees high towards the chest and pumping the arms quickly. Stay light on your feet and focus on speed and rhythm, aiming for fast turnover and minimal ground contact. Maintain posture and do not let the knees drop below hip height during the movement.

Exercise Name: Lunge Drops with Medicine Ball Punch
Exercise Description: Start in a split squat position holding a medicine ball at chest height. Lift your front foot slightly off the ground then allow gravity to drop you into a deeper split squat. As your front foot makes contact with the ground, explosively punch the medicine ball forward with both hands while maintaining torso stability. Absorb the landing with control before resetting.

Start in a standard push-up position with your hands placed directly under your shoulders. Bring your hands together to form a triangle shape with your thumbs and index fingers touching. Lower your chest towards the ground by
bending your elbows, keeping your body straight and your core engaged. Push yourself back up to the starting
position, fully extending your arms.

Start facing laterally with the barbell of a smith machine rested on one shoulder. Place your outside foot slightly ahead of you, while keeping your inside foot just behind you. Drop your back knee to the ground into a lunge position while controlling the weight. Push back up to your starting position.

Stand facing the landmine with one end grasped to your chest between two hands. Plant your feet
shoulder-width apart with a small bend at the knee. Press out in front of yourself as quickly as
possible, before slowly dropping back to your chest.

Place a barbell on your back. Drop as fast as possible into a 90 degree angle from the floor. Stop as quickly as possible at this point, then push upwards with force. Try to get into a consistent rhythm for the entire reps in the set.

Place a resistance band around your ankles and assume a slight squat position. Step laterally, keeping constant tension on the band and maintaining a low stance. Alternate steps while keeping your toes forward.
Sit on a bench with your feet hanging off. Using a resistance band or light weight, move your foot inwards (inversion) or outwards (eversion) in a controlled motion. Repeat for both movements.
Hold an EZ bar with an underhand grip, keeping your elbows close to your torso. Curl the bar up towards your chest, squeezing your biceps before lowering under control.
Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing forwards with quick, reactive contacts. Keep your knees slightly bent and ensure minimal ground contact time.

Stand perpendicular to a cable machine with the handle attached to the mid-pulley. Hold the handle with both hands at your chest, stepping away from the machine to create tension. Press the handle straight out in front of you, fully extending your arms. Once your arms are extended, rotate your torso away from the machine while keeping your arms extended. Rotate back to the centre, then bring the handle back to your chest with control.

Exercise Name: Single Leg Bosch Hold + Perturbation GHD
Exercise Description: Secure yourself on a GHD machine, keeping one leg locked in and the other extended freely. Hold your torso in a straight line, resisting movement. A partner may apply light perturbations for added challenge.
Stand on one leg on a foam pad, engaging your core and glutes to maintain balance. Avoid excessive foot movement and maintain control. Switch sides after completing the reps.
Lie on a flat bench, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. Lower the bar towards your forehead, keeping your elbows stationary, then extend back to the start. Control the movement throughout.

Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Engage your core and hip flexors, then lift your knees towards your chest in a controlled motion. Lower slowly back to the starting position before repeating. Avoid swinging.

Adjust the seat height so your knees are slightly bent at the bottom of the pedal stroke. Maintain a steady pace at moderate intensity, focusing on consistent breathing and form. Aim to keep a comfortable cadence
without overexerting yourself.
Hold dumbbells with a neutral grip (palms facing inwards). Curl the weights towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows stationary. Lower under control and repeat.

Attach a resistance band to a sturdy anchor at elbow height. Stand sideways to the anchor and hold the band with your outside hand. Keeping your elbow tucked to your side at 90 degrees, rotate your forearm outward against the band’s resistance. Hold the end range briefly before slowly returning to the start. Avoid using your shoulder or upper body to assist; the movement should come from the rotator cuff muscles.
Stand with your feet wide apart. Shift your weight to one side, lowering into a lateral squat while keeping the opposite leg straight. Push back up and alternate sides.
Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing forwards diagonally with quick, reactive movements. Keep knees slightly bent and minimal ground contact time.

Sit down on an upright bench with your back straight. Poke your best upwards and raise the dumbbells so that your
elbows are out to the side at shoulder-height. Press upwards above your head and then slowly drop to the starting position for 1 rep.

Kneel adjacent to a wall with your knee farthest from the wall on the ground and the nearer foot planted on the ground. Hold a light medicine ball against your chest. From this position, explosively turn your farthest hip in towards the wall and in the motion rotate your upper body toward the wall also, releasing the ball with force as your shoulders turn to face the wall. Use your upper torso and arm in unison. After the toss  reset. The movement should be crisp, driven by rotational power from the hip, core and upper back, not just the arm. Switch sides after completing the reps.

Lie on your back with your feet on sliders (socks on a hard surface can work too). Perform a glute bridge and slowly slide your feet away from your body while keeping your hips elevated. Pull your feet back to the starting position.

Place a dumbbell on the floor between your feet and stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Hinge at the hips and grip the dumbbell with one hand using a neutral grip - palm facing inwards - while keeping the chest up and back flat. Drive forcefully through your legs and hips to extend upwards, pulling the dumbbell vertically by leading with the elbow. As the dumbbell rises past chest height, rotate your hand and punch straight overhead, locking out the arm at full extension. Catch it in a stable standing position and hold briefly before lowering back to the floor. Reset between each rep. The power should come from the hips, with the arm simply guiding the movement.
Stand on one leg, holding a kettlebell with both hands. Pass the kettlebell around your body, maintaining balance and core engagement. Switch directions after completing the reps.
Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, keeping your core engaged. Lift one knee towards your chest, hold briefly, then switch legs in a marching motion. Avoid excessive swinging.

From a neutral position, with each feet under its corresponding shoulder and on the balls of your feet, drop one knee down and backwards into a reverse lunge position. As soon as the ball of your foot on this side touches the ground, immediately push off forwards from both feet. Land in the same staggered position reverse lunge, but forwards from your original position and hold momentarily before resetting for the next rep.

Stand on one leg with your eyes closed in an athletic stance. A teammate should push or your body at various points (shoulders, hips, back) to test your balance. Focus on maintaining stability by engaging your core and adjusting your weight subtly to counter the external force.

Start with one foot slightly in front of the other shoulder-width apart. With a small bend in the knees, push off both feet to bounce forwards about the distance of one step. In the air, shift your weight backwards onto the back foot and upon landing, immediately bounce backwards to your starting position. Aim for minimal time between each bounce but hold in that starting position, ensuring you keep your centre of mass neutral and slightly in the direction you will next travel e.g. forwards for the first bounce and backwards on the second bounce. Think about stepping in to close the distance on an opponent defensively but immediately retreating in case they push the ball into space beyond you.

Hold a dumbbell in one hand and press it fully overhead, keeping your arm locked out and core engaged. Walk forward with controlled, steady steps, ensuring your torso remains upright and your hips stay level. Avoid leaning to one side or allowing the weight to drift forward. Maintain tension in your shoulders, core and glutes throughout. Once the distance or time is completed, switch arms and repeat on the other side.
Sit at a cable row machine, gripping the handle with both hands. Pull the handle towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Return under control and repeat.

Start with both of your heels on the edge of a box and then step off, allowing gravity to take you towards the ground. Immediately jump as far as possible while keeping ground contact time short. In the air, rotate your hip round 90 degrees and land into a squat facing to the side.

Lean forward and drive through your legs, pushing a weighted sled (prowler) across the floor. Maintain a low forward body position and a strong arm drive. Keep a consistent stride and focus on powerful acceleration.

Start in a half-kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the other leg bent in front of you at a 90-degree angle. Tuck your pelvis slightly by engaging your glutes, and shift your hips forward until you feel a stretch in the hip flexor of your rear leg. Keep your chest upright and avoid overarching your lower back. For a deeper stretch, raise the arm on the same side as the kneeling leg and reach slightly overhead and across your body.

Stand on one leg, bringing your opposite knee to hip height while keeping your ankle dorsiflexed. Maintain this position without swaying, engaging your glutes and core to stabilise. Hold for the prescribed time.

Exercise Name: World's Greatest + Lunge Hold with Rotation
Exercise Description: Step into a long lunge with your hands on the floor inside the front foot. Keep the back leg straight and hips low. Lift the inside arm and rotate your torso, opening the chest fully towards the front leg. Hold this position briefly, then return the hand to the ground and maintain the lunge hold for an extra moment before stepping back. Repeat on the other side. Emphasise length through the spine and controlled rotation.

Stand upright with one foot resting lightly on top of a medium-sized exercise ball beside you. Keeping the standing leg straight but not locked, slowly allow the foot on the ball to roll outward, lengthening the inner thigh. Maintain a tall posture and avoid leaning. Once you reach a controlled end range, engage the adductors of the standing leg to return to the start. Keep the movement smooth and avoid letting the ball roll too far out of control.

Perform three high-knee marching steps, lifting your knees to waist height while keeping your core tight and posture upright. On the third step, transition into an immediate controlled deceleration, lowering into a stable position by absorbing force through your glutes and quads. Ensure your landing is controlled and balanced.
Begin in a prone position with sliders under your feet and hands. Extend opposite arm and leg simultaneously, maintaining core stability. Control the return before switching sides.
Accelerate as quickly as possible while maintaining straight legs rather than the usual bend at the knee. Once you reach a fast speed, switch into regular sprinting form for the remaining distance.
Perform the Prone Hip Extension, but with a slow eccentric phase to focus on glute and hamstring control. Keep your core engaged throughout.

Initiate a skipping motion, driving one knee upwards so that it Is parallel to the ground or higher. Swing the opposite arm forward to mimic sprinting mechanics. Land softly on the balls of your feet and immediately spring into the next skip, minimising contact time with the ground.

Stand tall with a barbell in front of you, holding it with a shoulder-width overhand grip. Keeping the bar close to your body, pull it upwards towards your chin, leading with your elbows. Pause briefly at the top, then lower it under control back to the start. Maintain a stable posture and avoid excessive shrugging.

Start with a resisted band connected around your waist and stand laterally away from the band holder. Leap away from the band holder so that the band comes under tension. Immediately swing your back hip round towards the band holder and begin to sprint in that direction. The band holder can let go after this turn and move out of the way while you continue to sprint through 10 metres.

Set a series of low hurdles spaced evenly. Begin with feet shoulder-width apart and hop over each hurdle continuously without pausing, landing with soft knees and quickly reloading into the next jump. Focus on minimal ground contact time and consistent rhythm. Use the arms to maintain momentum and keep your chest tall throughout the sequence.

Stand in an athletic stance and load your hips by dropping slightly. Swing your arms and jump forward explosively, landing softly on both feet. Absorb the landing through the hips and reset before repeating.

Start on your toes with arms raised above head to stretch as tall as possible. Throw your heels down to the ground violently at the same time as your arms and entire weight. You should finish in a
controlled squat position. From there, immediately leap as far in front of yourself as possible. Upon
landing in the same squatted position, maintain momentum while immediately jumping as high as
possible into the air. Have your partner throw the ball in at a 
challenging height you can only reach at full stretch. The aim is to get any touch on the ball.

Exercise Name:
Drop Jump + Split Squat +
Lateral Hop
Exercise Description:
Start with both of your heels on the edge of a box and then step off, allowing gravity to take you towards the ground. Immediately jump vertically. Land this jump in a split squat with one leg out in
front of you and the other’s knee facing down towards the ground. Having controlled the
momentum in this split squat, hop laterally to the side off of your front foot as far as possible onto the original back foot. That means hopping off the left foot onto the right if the left foot is out in front of you in the split squat and vice versa for the other side.
Lie on your side with a foam roller or yoga block between your knees. Squeeze the roller and hold for 10 seconds before releasing. This strengthens the adductors and supports pelvic alignment.

Shuffle laterally, then turn 90 degrees into a full sprint. Focus on quick transitions and explosive push offs. Open your hips on the turn and whip the back hip around first before attacking the ground to accelerate off in a smooth motion.

Secure yourself face down on a GHD machine, maintaining a neutral spine and extended hip position. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to hold your torso in a straight line. A partner may apply light perturbations for added challenge.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip. Hinge at the hips, keeping your back flat while slightly bending your knees for stability. Keep your chest lifted and shoulders back, then explosively pull the bar towards your lower chest by driving your elbows backward. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, then lower the bar back to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Start in a half-kneeling position, with your back knee on the ground and front foot flat. Hold a dumbbell in the hand opposite to the front leg at shoulder height. Keep your core engaged and press the dumbbell overhead, avoiding excessive leaning. Lower under control before repeating.

Lie on your side next to a bench and position your top leg on the bench with your knee bent at 90 degrees. Support yourself on your forearm and lift your hips, keeping your bottom leg off the ground. Hold this position while keeping your core engaged and hips aligned. To regress, lower your bottom knee to the floor for extra support.

Face a wall and place your toes a few inches away from it. Bend your knee and gently drive it toward the wall, keeping your heel planted. Move your knee in and out from the wall based on your mobility.

Hold a barbell in the front rack position while walking slowly and deliberately, ensuring minimal movement of the barbell. Maintain core engagement and an upright posture to stabilise against barbell instability.

Exercise Name: Prone Jack Knife w Slider Unilateral
Exercise Description: Perform the Prone Jack Knife w Slider, but with one leg extended while the other drives towards the chest. Alternate sides while maintaining core stability.

Tie a large resistance band to a squat rack frame or similarly sturdy object at shoulder-height. Kneel down in front of the frame while facing away from it and hold the end of the resistance band in both hands in front of you. Fall forwards in a Nordic motion while extending your legs to straighten with your face towards the floor. The band should go under tension as you drop to ease your motion and slow the descent.

Start from a neutral position standing and on the balls of your feet. Lift both feet slightly off the ground such that gravity pulls you down towards the ground. Allow your body to fall into a squatted position by dropping your hips back and simultaneously hinge forwards at the hips to keep your shoulders over your toes. Stick the landing point and hold momentarily.
Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing backwards diagonally with quick, reactive movements. Keep knees slightly bent and minimal ground contact time.
Lie on an incline bench, holding dumbbells with an underhand grip. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows stationary. Lower under control and repeat.

Position yourself on all fours facing a wall, with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your knees just off the ground so that they hover an inch or two above the floor – keeping your back flat and core braced. Now press each hand firmly against the wall in front of you while your feet stay planted. Hold this position by actively pressing into the wall with your palms and pushing your heels backwards as if dragging the floor. The goal is full tension across the core, shoulders and hips while maintaining perfect posture. Keep the neck neutral and avoid arching through the lower back. Breathe steadily while holding. If unable to complete without affecting your posture, drop the duration but focus on the technique.

Start with one foot slightly in front of the other shoulder-width apart. With a small bend in the knees, push off both feet to bounce laterally to one side only about the distance of one step. In the air, shift your weight backwards onto the back foot and upon landing by opening that hip and dropping the knee slightly on the same side, then immediately bounce backwards to your starting position. Aim for minimal time between each bounce but hold in that starting position, ensuring you keep your centre of mass neutral and slightly in the direction you will next travel. Think about stepping past the ball but immediately retreating behind it again.

Exercise Name: Long Lever Bosch Hold - Unilateral GHD
Exercise Description: Position yourself on a GHD machine, securing one leg while the other remains free. Maintain a straight body position, engaging your core and hamstrings to resist movement. Hold the position. A partner may apply perturbations for added challenge.

Exercise Name: Double Leg Bosch Hold + Perturbation GHD
Exercise Description: Secure yourself in a GHD machine, maintaining a neutral spine and a straight-line position. A partner applies perturbations (light pressure) to challenge stability. Engage your glutes, hamstrings and core to resist movement. Hold for the prescribed time.
Perform the crossover step repeatedly in one direction, maintaining quick, controlled foot movements and ensuring minimal ground contact time. Keep your upper body stable and vision forward.

Start in a push-up position. Lower your chest to the floor with control and press back up explosively. On the way up, step one foot forward to plant into a deep lunge position. Hold briefly, then return to push-up position and repeat on the other side. Keep the back flat and hips stable throughout the transitions.

Stand facing lateral to a cable machine with the handle positioned at the lowest setting. Grip the handle with your outside hand, arm straight down at your side and elbow slightly bent. Brace your core and maintain a stable stance with your knees slightly bent. Lift your arm directly out to the side and away from the machine, until your hand reaches shoulder height, keeping your elbow slightly bent. Pause briefly at the top, maintaining tension in your shoulder, then slowly return to the starting position. Avoid shrugging your shoulder upwards or using momentum to lift the weight. Complete all repetitions on one side before switching to the other.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip in front of your thighs. Engage your
core and keep your back straight. With a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips to lower the barbell towards the
ground, keeping it close to your legs. Lower the barbell until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, ensuring your back
remains straight. From this position, engage your glutes and hamstrings to return to the starting position by extending
your hips. Focus on maintaining control throughout the movement, emphasising the eccentric phase of the lift.

Lie on your back with one knee bent and foot planted while keeping the other leg extended straight. Engage your core and glutes, pressing through your heel to lift your hips until your body forms a straight line. Hold briefly at the top before lowering with control. Keep your hips level throughout the movement.

Secure your feet in a glute-ham developer (GHD) or under a stable anchor, keeping your knees on the pad. Start upright with a straight torso, then lower yourself towards the ground, maintaining control by engaging your glutes and hamstrings. Once at the bottom, pull yourself back up explosively, avoiding excessive use of the lower back.

Start on all fours with your wrists under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Place one hand behind your head with your elbow pointing out to the side. Rotate your torso, bringing your elbow down towards your opposite arm, then open up by rotating your elbow toward the ceiling. Keep your hips stable throughout the movement.

Stand tall with your feet shoulder-width apart. Quickly drop into a quarter squat, keeping your chest up and arms swinging back. Without pausing at the bottom, explode upwards, extending your hips, knees and ankles fully. Land softly, absorbing the impact through your legs before resetting.

Attach a resistance band to a low or mid-height anchor and stand sideways to the anchor point. Hold the band with one hand and extend your opposite arm overhead. Keeping your core engaged, lean sideways away from the anchor, feeling a deep stretch in your lat. Return to the starting position with control and repeat before switching sides.

Attach a resistance band around your waist, securing it to a side anchor. Perform a crossover step, stepping laterally and crossing one foot over the other while resisting the pull of the band. Keep your hips stable and maintain quick footwork.

Assume a plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line from head to heels. Engage
your core and glutes to maintain stability. Extend one arm straight out in front of you while simultaneously lifting the
opposite leg off the ground. Hold this position for a few seconds, ensuring your hips and shoulders remain level. Lower your arm and leg back to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side. Continue alternating sides for as long
as possible.

Stand a few inches away from a wall with your toes pointed straight ahead. Keeping your heel planted, drive your knee forward towards the wall without lifting your heel. If you reach the wall easily, step slightly farther back and repeat. Maintain a neutral foot position and avoid collapsing your arch or letting your knee drift excessively inward or outward.

Hold onto a bar above your head with both arms so that you are hanging in the air. From this position, bring both legs upwards so that they hold a straight line directly in front of you. Your body should form an L-shape if seen from the side. Hold this position for as long as possible. If you are unable to create the L-shape at all, lower both legs slightly to the ground but maintain them in a straight line out in front of you.

Attach a resistance band to a low anchor and hold it with one hand under slight tension. Stand on the opposite leg and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight and extending the free leg behind you. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstring, then return to standing.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands in front of you. Engage your core and keep your chest up. Hinge at the hips and bend your knees slightly, allowing the kettlebell to swing back between your legs. From this position, explosively extend your hips, driving them forward to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height. Allow the kettlebell to swing back down between your legs as you hinge at the hips again. Focus on using your hips to generate power, rather than your arms. Repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions, maintaining a rhythmic and powerful motion.
Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, pressing the weights overhead until arms are fully extended. Lower under control and repeat. Keep your core engaged throughout.

Lean forward into an acceleration position against the sled, keeping your knees high and driving forcefully through the ground. Sprint for the designated distance, focusing on maintaining consistent knee drive and explosive power.

Exercise Name: Standing Knee Hugs with Ankle Rolls
Exercise Description: Pull one knee towards your chest, hold it for a few seconds while rotating your ankle to activate the ankle joint. Perform on each side.

Attach a resistance band around your waist, anchoring it behind you. Start in a split squat position with your front foot planted. Lift your front foot slightly, allowing gravity to drop you into a deeper lunge before pushing back up. Maintain core stability throughout.

Set up a series of cones in a zigzag pattern, spaced 5m apart. Sprint to each cone, cutting sharply to the next cone while maintaining balance and control. Focus on quick direction changes and staying light on your feet during the transitions.

Stand in a split stance, holding a cable or resistance band at chest height. Press the handle forwards, resisting rotation. After each rep, switch your lead foot and repeat. A partner may apply perturbations for added challenge.

Start in a deep lunge position with one leg out in front of the other. Push through the ground to jump forwards, 
simultaneously bringing the back leg forwards to become the new lead foot as you land in a lunge again. As soon as
you land, immediately repeat this action for the next rep.
Lie face down on the floor, extending your arms and legs straight. Lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground simultaneously, squeezing your glutes and lower back, then lower under control.

Lie on your side with a foam roller or lacrosse ball placed under your lat or glute. Apply pressure by shifting your weight onto the ball, then slowly rotate your torso (for lats) or your hip (for glutes) internally and externally to floss through tight spots. Move slowly, stopping at any areas of restriction and maintaining deep, controlled breathing.

Start on one foot in a sprinting position ready to push off. Hop forwards onto a low box cc 4", landing on the opposite foot and pausing atop the box in a sprinting position again. Push off again with another powerful step forwards off the low box to land on the opposite foot in a sprinting position once more. Reset and repeat in the opposite direction.

Hold a barbell at shoulder height with your hands just wider than shoulder-width apart. Dip slightly at the knees, then explosively extend your hips and knees while pressing the bar overhead. Lower the bar back to shoulder height and repeat. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell at shoulder height. Dip slightly at the knees, then drive through your legs to press the barbell overhead. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height under control.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent, and weight distributed on the balls of your feet. Keep your eyes focused on the screen, ready to react. Have a random number generator or colour selector on screen to dictate your movement. You can set cones up to correspond with these at various distances and angles from your start point (up to 10m in any direction). As soon as you set yourself at the starting position, watch for the next colour change then immediately drive off your back foot, keeping your strides quick and powerful. Reach the cone or dictated point and drop through your hips with a slight forward lean and importantly neutral body weight to tap the cone. Focus on maintaining proper sprint mechanics, with your arms driving naturally and your chest leaning slightly forward before stabilising into a neutral position at the time of the tap.

Attach a resistance band around your waist, anchoring it behind you. Start in a low forward-leaning sprint position and drive forcefully into acceleration, maintaining strong knee drive and arm mechanics.
Rather than bending your knees as with a normal sprint, move as quickly as possible across the distance while kicking your legs out in front of you straight-legged.

Start in a slight squat position with your feet hip-width apart and your core engaged. Push off with your back foot, crossing it over your front foot and planting it with force as you bound laterally in one direction. Upon landing, use the momentum and force generated from the plant to immediately push off again, continuing to bound in the same direction. The goal is to maximise distance covered with each bound, maintaining a fluid and dynamic motion.

Lie on your back with one leg extended and the other raised in the air. Slowly extend and flex the raised leg while keeping tension in the hamstring. Perform with controlled movement, ensuring no excessive hip rotation.

Stand in front of a cable machine, facing away from the low pulley with two handles attached. Hold the handle at chest height with both hands and step into a split stance. Lower yourself into a split squat, bending both knees until your back knee is just above the floor. As you rise from the squat, press the cable handle diagonally upward and out in front of you, fully extending your arms. Bring the handle back to your chest as you reset for the next rep. Focus on a smooth, controlled movement and engage your core to stabilise throughout.

Exercise Name: Split Stance Balance with Band Pull
Exercise Description: Stand in a split stance position with a resistance band anchored in front of you. Hold the band with both hands and engage your core as you pull the band toward your chest, maintaining balance in the split stance. Keep the movement controlled, ensuring minimal sway while stabilising through your front foot and midline.
Hold TRX handles with an overhand grip, leaning back with your body in a straight line. Row your chest towards the handles, keeping your elbows close to your sides. Lower under control and repeat.

Stand facing a wall with your feet a few feet away and lean into it at a 45° angle. Place your forearms or hands against the wall at shoulder height with elbows bent. Keeping your torso firm and ribs down, slide your arms upward along the wall until fully extended overhead, maintaining consistent contact throughout. Slide back down to the start under control without losing body angle or allowing the spine to arch.

Start in a lunge position with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Lower your back knee toward the ground, then explode upward into a jump, switching leg positions mid-air. Land softly with your opposite leg forward and immediately transition into the next repetition. Focus on maintaining an upright torso and engaging your core for balance.
Perform the Prone Bosch Hold on a GHD machine, but with one leg secured and the other extended freely. Maintain core and hip stability throughout the hold.

Stand with your feet together to one side of a line on the floor. Bend your hips and knees sightly. Jump to the opposite side of the line and land on your toes. Continue jumping from side to side landing on your toes. Aim to spend as little time in contact with the floor as possible.

Stand tall next to a stable surface, such as a fence or pole, for balance. Shift your weight onto one leg and swing the opposite leg forward and backward in a controlled motion. Keep your torso upright, your core engaged, and avoid arching your back. Start with a small range of motion and gradually increase the height of the swing as your hip flexors and hamstrings loosen. Repeat all reps on one leg before switching to the other.

Sit on the edge of a bench or floor, keeping one leg extended straight out with your heel resting on the surface. Point and flex your toes repeatedly while gently leaning your torso forward, maintaining a straight back. If needed, add a band around your foot for additional tension. Move through the range with slow, controlled motion, ensuring your hamstring lengthens and contracts dynamically rather than forcing a static stretch.

Stand with a resistance band looped around your feet. Drive one knee up to hip height against the resistance, then return slowly to the starting position. Maintain a controlled motion and alternate legs.

Lie flat on your back with your legs raised and knees bent at 90 degrees. Engage your core and hip flexors, keeping both legs still in this position. Maintain tension in the core and ensure your lower back remains in contact with the ground. Hold for the prescribed time.

Start lateral to the barbell with your inside hand holding it up. Your aim is to lift it up to hip height while also rotating your body to face towards the barbell. Quickly bring your back arm round to push the barbell the rest of the way up to head height. Imagine the rotational force of a punch as you twist your body and force rises from your feet all the way through the weight as quickly as possible.

Place a weight plate or dumbbell between your thighs. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. Start by engaging your shoulder blades, pulling them down and back. Drive your chest upwards explosively until your chin clears the bar, keeping your body straight without excessive swinging. Lower yourself under control to the starting position and reset before the next repetition.
Lie flat on your back with your arms extended overhead. Engage your core and rotate your body in a controlled rolling motion, maintaining tension throughout. Reverse the movement and repeat.

Begin in a tall kneeling position, keeping your hips extended. Hinge backwards at the hips, maintaining a neutral spine, then return to upright by engaging your glutes and hamstrings. Control the movement throughout.

Attach a resistance band low around a stable anchor and loop it around your waist. Adopt a wide squat stance and drop into a deep position with your chest upright. Allow the band to pull your hips laterally while you resist and shift your weight side-to-side. As you shift, straighten the trailing leg and load the opposite hip. Keep the movement fluid, maintaining tension in the band and a strong position through your trunk.

Kneel with one leg in front and the other leg behind, forming a 90-degree angle with your front knee. Push your hips forward to stretch
the hip flexors. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the starting position.

Stand sideways to a box or step, placing your inside foot on the platform. Drive through your lead foot, stepping up and bringing your opposite knee up to hip height. Lower under control before switching sides.
Stand sideways to a box or step, placing your inside foot on the platform. Drive through your foot, stepping up while keeping your torso upright. Lower under control before switching sides.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Step your right foot across and behind your left, landing in a deep crossover lunge. As you lower into the lunge, press both dumbbells overhead. Return to standing and bring the weights back to shoulder height. Repeat on the other side. Focus on balance and smooth coordination between the lower body step and the overhead press.

Stand facing a wall with your hands pressed against it at shoulder height, leaning forward at a 45-degree angle. Begin with one knee lifted to waist height, keeping your toe dorsiflexed (pointed up) and your opposite leg extended behind you. In one quick and forceful movement, switch legs by driving your rear knee up while simultaneously bringing the other foot down. Maintain a tall posture, active core and stiff ankle position to reinforce efficient sprint mechanics. Focus on minimising ground contact time and keeping your switches crisp and explosive.

Assume a regular press-up position. Drop quickly to the ground and then push off as powerfully as possible. On the way up, bring one knee up towards your chest and step into a lunge position. Switch your arms into sprinting position with one up and one down by your side (alternate to legs).

Stand in a split stance with your back foot elevated on a bench or step and your front foot firmly planted on the ground. Keeping your torso upright and core engaged, lower your back knee toward the ground, ensuring your front knee stays aligned with your toes. Push through your front heel and midfoot to return to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Begin with a bounding sprint for 10m, taking exaggerated strides and driving your knees high to cover more ground. Transition smoothly into a regular sprint for the next 10m, focusing on maintaining speed and power.

Start by standing on a 20-25 inch box. Step off, landing softly on the balls of your feet with your knees slightly bent. Control the landing then explode upward into a maximum-height vertical jump, with a shorter ground contact time. Land softly again and reset before the next rep. Maintain a neutral spine and engage your core throughout the movement.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs. With a soft bend in the knees and a flat back, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your shins. At the bottom of the hinge, pause and pull the dumbbells towards your ribs by driving your elbows back. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the row, then lower the weights and return to standing. Keep tension in your hamstrings and do not round your spine.

Set up a starting point and ensure you have enough open space to sprint and change direction effectively. Begin in an athletic stance, leaning slightly forward with your knees bent and weight on the balls of your feet. On an audio cue (e.g., "90," "180," or "270") react immediately to the instruction:

90/270 Degrees - Plant your outside foot and pivot sharply to sprint in the indicated direction.

180 Degrees = Decelerate slightly, hinging forward at the hips and turn the corner to accelerate out in the opposite direction with as much speed as possible.

Retain speed while changing directions and continue until all seven cues have been performed.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Step sideways into a deep lateral lunge, bending your outside knee while keeping your inside leg straight. As you lower, reach both hands toward your foot to deepen the stretch and reinforce balance. Push through your bent leg to return to standing, keeping your core engaged and chest upright throughout.
Kneel on one knee with the other leg extended straight out to the side. Slowly push your hips back while keeping your back straight, then return to the start.

Set up a barbell in a squat rack at just below knee height. Assume a wide sumo stance with feet turned slightly outward. Grip the bar just inside your knees with an overhand or mixed grip. Engage your core and pull your shoulder blades back. Drive through your heels, extending your hips and knees simultaneously to stand tall. Squeeze your glutes at the top before lowering the bar back to the rack under control. Ensure a neutral spine and avoid excessive rounding or leaning forward.

Stand on a raised surface, keeping one foot off the edge. Slowly lower your hanging foot towards the floor, tapping your heel lightly before returning to the start. Maintain control and knee alignment throughout.

Start in a staggered stance with one foot slightly behind the other. Explode forward for 5m at maximum effort, focusing on driving through
the ground with a planted foot. Decelerate to reset your position with the opposite foot forwards, then repeat for another 5m. Complete all the sprints then recover fully between sets.

Start with your feet shoulder-width apart, a slight bend in your knees and a forward lean with a straight back. Hold a 
dumbbell in each hand just in front of each knee and row these up to your waist. Slowly drop each at the same time
back to the start position.

Start in a marching position, lifting one knee to waist height with your toes dorsiflexed. Quickly switch both legs simultaneously, bringing the opposite knee up while driving the initial knee down aggressively. Maintain an upright posture and controlled arm action, ensuring a smooth, efficient switch between positions.

Set the cable handles just below shoulder height so that tension only begins when the handles are held close to your chest. Stand in a split stance and grip one handle in each hand. Step forward slightly to preload the cables, holding the handles at shoulder level with elbows bent and palms facing forward. From this position, press both handles forward a short distance - just enough to extend the arms partially while maintaining tension. Stop before locking out, then return under control to the start. Keep your core braced and avoid leaning into the press. The goal is to generate explosive force through a limited range while resisting backward pull from the cables.

Stand beside a low box in a sprint position with your outside foot on the ground and inside knee high just above the low box. Alternate your standing foot while mimicking sprint mechanics, keeping your torso upright and pumping your arms in coordination with your legs. Quickly step the inside foot on the low box then return your weight back to the outside foot to return to the starting position. Pause momentarily to regain full balance and then repeat for the desired reps on one side.

Start with the barbell on a squat rack at shoulder height. Position it across your upper back while gripping the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width. With feet shoulder-width apart, lift the bar off the rack and step back into position. Keep your chest up and core engaged as you lower into a squat, ensuring your thighs are parallel to the ground or deeper. Push through your heels to return to standing. Gradually add weight to determine your one-rep maximum

Step into a deep lunge position, ensuring your front knee is at 90 degrees and your back knee hovers just above the ground. Hold this position while maintaining an upright torso and core engagement. Keep even weight distribution between the front and back legs to reinforce stability and control.

Stand tall and pull one ankle towards your glutes, holding it with your hand for a quad stretch. Extend the opposite arm overhead to improve balance and stretch the front of your body. Alternate sides.

Start with both of your heels on the edge of a box and then step off, allowing gravity to take you towards the ground. Immediately jump as far as possible while keeping ground contact time short. In the air, rotate your hip round 90 degrees and land into a squat facing to the side. Immediately
shuffle your feet laterally at speed for a couple of steps back towards the box. Again, lead off the foot closest to the box and avoid crossing your feet.

While sat down, start with each dumbbell just over shoulder height and relatively tight in towards your body. Press directly vertical to a point just before your arms lock out (slight bend kept in
elbow), then lower back down into the starting position.

Lie flat on your back with your arms and legs fully extended to create a long line on the floor. Lift both your arms and
legs slightly off the ground to start. From there, bring them towards each other powerfully while twisting your body in
a circle. Drop your arms and legs back towards the floor to extend out in a line, but do not touch the ground. Continue
to repeat until a full circle has been completed on the spot, then move in the opposite direction.
Lean against an incline bench, holding dumbbells with an underhand grip. Curl the weights up towards your shoulders, keeping your upper arms stationary. Lower under control.

Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell overhead in one hand while stepping into a deep lunge. Maintain core engagement and overhead stability throughout. Push back up to the start position. Alternate sides each rep.

Stand in a split stance with your back foot elevated on a bench or step and your front foot positioned on a small plate or wedge to elevate the heel. Hold dumbbells at your sides or a single dumbbell at your chest for added resistance. Keeping your torso upright and core engaged, lower your back knee toward the floor by bending your front knee. Ensure your front knee tracks forward but remains stable, then push through your front foot and midfoot to return to standing. Focus on controlling the descent and maintaining balance.

Start in a press-up position with knees rested on the ground. Place the resistance band around one knee and the heel of the opposite foot. From this position, drive the connected heel straight behind you in a swift, powerful motion, extending your leg fully back. Your hips should remain square to the front, and the movement should be initiated from your hip joint, not your lower back. You should feel a strong contraction in your glutes as you execute the kickback. After reaching the peak of your movement, with your leg fully extended behind you, slowly return your foot to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Set a cable at chest height and stand perpendicular to it. Hold the handle with both hands directly in front of your chest, resisting the rotational pull of the cable. Maintain this position statically for time. Keep the shoulders square and hips stable, focusing on anti-rotation through the core. Do not allow the cable to twist your torso or shift your balance.

Start in a quadruped position (on all fours) with your wrists under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Reach one arm under your body, rotating your torso while keeping your hips square. Allow your shoulder and head to move toward the floor, feeling a stretch through your upper back and shoulders. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. Keep the movement slow and controlled, focusing on deepening the stretch with each rep.

Begin in a kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the other foot flat to your side at a 90-degree angle. Shift your weight laterally toward the bent leg, lowering your hips and stretching the inner thigh of the extended leg. Push back to the starting position and repeat, then switch sides.

Set a watt bike to level-3 resistance. The aim is to achieve the highest average cadence / watts across a 30-minute period.
Only one attempt is needed to gauge your score for this test.

Start in a half-kneeling position, with your back knee on the ground and front foot flat. Hold a dumbbell in the hand opposite to the front leg at shoulder height. Keep your core engaged and press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended, avoiding excessive leaning. Lower the dumbbell under control back to the start position before repeating. Maintain a stable posture throughout.

Start in a wide stance. Gently rock weight into one hip, feeling the load through the inside edge of the foot. Hold, then bound gently into the opposite leg, landing softly and controlled. Focus on feel, not height or speed.

Lie on an incline bench with your feet planted firmly on the ground and your back pressed into the bench. Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width, ensuring your wrists are in a strong position. Lower the bar towards your upper chest in a controlled manner, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the bar back up explosively, ensuring full elbow extension at the top.
Perform a TRX row in a slightly more upright position, keeping your core tight. Pull your chest towards the handles, then lower under control. Maintain proper shoulder positioning.

Begin lying flat on a bench, feet firmly planted on the ground. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width and lift it off the rack, holding it above your chest with arms fully extended. Lower the barbell to your chest in a controlled motion, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle, then press it back up to the starting position. Incrementally increase the weight to identify your one-rep maximum.

Exercise Name: Prone Jack Knife w Slider Bilateral
Exercise Description: Begin in a prone plank position with sliders under both feet. Drive your knees towards your chest, keeping your core engaged. Extend your legs back slowly to maintain control.

Begin on all fours with your wrists under your shoulders and knees under your hips. For cat, round your back by tucking your pelvis and chin, drawing your belly button upward. For cow, arch your back by dropping your belly and lifting your head and tailbone. Move smoothly between these two positions.
Perform a split-step movement, alternating between left, left, right or other set patterns, focusing on quick, controlled foot contacts. Maintain an upright posture and minimal ground contact time.
Bound off each foot diagonally in front of you with powerful strides, covering as much distance as possible with each bound.

Stand with your heels elevated on a small plate or wedge while holding a dumbbell at chest height. Lower into a deep squat, keeping your torso upright and knees tracking forward. Pause briefly at the bottom before pushing through the midfoot and heels to return to standing.
