Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a plate or dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Lower yourself into a squat by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back flat. As you reach the bottom of the squat, explode upwards into a jump, swinging the plates/dumbbells forward and upward to help generate upward momentum. Aim to jump as high as possible, then land softly with bent knees, immediately lowering into the next squat for the following rep.
Start by dropping to one side into a lateral lunge. From this dropped position, immediately lift the back leg up and across the front leg to accelerate out into a short sprint.
Stand on the balls of your feet and bounce laterally side to side, keeping your knees slightly bent and ensuring quick, reactive movements. Maintain minimal ground contact time.
Step laterally into a deep lunge while keeping your opposite leg straight. As you reach the bottom, rotate your torso toward the bent knee, hold briefly, then return to standing.

Start in a plank position in front of a Keiser machine with cable attachment. While maintaining this position, extend one arm in front of you to grab a hold of the cable. This is your starting position. From there, pull the cable towards your shoulder while pulling your elbow back and in towards your side. Make this movement as powerfully as possible, then slowly return the cable back to complete the rep.

Kneel down on one leg in a lunge position. Hold cables in alternate hands so that they cross over each other to create an X-shape. Slowly extend your arms back towards the cable machine while maintaining the tension. At speed, pull backwards towards each hip with your arms, core, and upper body.

Stand sideways to the cable machine, gripping the handle with both hands at chest height. Rotate your torso explosively, pushing the handle outwards and across your body. Control the return before repeating. Keep your core engaged and hips stable throughout the movement.

From a neutral position, with each feet under its corresponding shoulder and on the balls of your feet, open one hip to the side such that the corresponding foot faces out in that direction too. Immediately, whip the hip on the other side around the corner to face the same direction laterally and use this momentum to sprint into a leap as far as possible in the same direction.

Exercise Name: Overhead Distraction with Lat/External Rotation Bias
Exercise Description: Anchor a resistance band overhead and grip it with one hand, palm facing forward. Step back slightly to create tension and allow the band to pull your arm upward. Lean your body slightly away from the anchored point to stretch your lat and shoulder. Rotate your arm externally by turning your thumb upward for an additional stretch. Hold for the desired time, then switch arms.

Shuffle laterally, keeping a low athletic stance. Focus on quick, explosive movements and staying low to the ground. Reverse direction by staying low and shifting your weight towards the new direction with the drop of a knee. Maintain
a low position throughout and avoid crossing your feet. Keep your movements quick and controlled, focusing on maintaining a low centre of gravity.

Lie on your side with your bottom leg extended straight and your top leg bent at the knee, with the foot placed flat in front of your lower thigh. Keep your core engaged and torso stable as you lift your bottom leg off the ground, squeezing your inner thigh at the top. Lower back down slowly and under control, avoiding any twisting of the hips.

Start on top of a box facing laterally. Stand with one foot on the edge of a box with the other foot hanging off the side. Step off the box to land on the same foot and immediately move into a lateral skip. Make sure to lead off your front foot with the back leg following rather than crossing your feet.
Stand in front of a box or step, holding a dumbbell in the same hand as your stepping leg. Drive through your foot, stepping up while keeping your torso upright. Lower under control and repeat.
Start in an athletic stance, stepping your outside leg across your body, followed by your trailing foot. Maintain a low position and continue the movement fluidly while staying light on your feet.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and keep your chest upright. Slowly bend your knees to lower into a squat while keeping your heels fully planted on the ground. Unlike a regular squat, your goal is to keep your torso more vertical and let your knees travel forward over your toes while maintaining full foot contact. Hold the bottom position for 2-3 seconds, ensuring your heels do not lift. Push through the balls of your feet and midfoot to return to standing.

Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, hinge at the hips to bring your torso forward at a 45-degree angle while keeping your back flat. Row one dumbbell up, driving the elbow back, then lower it under control before switching sides. Keep your core engaged to avoid rotation.

Kneel into a lunge directly lateral to a wall. Hold a medicine ball between your hands and rotate your upper body away from the wall. Then, as quickly as possible, thrust round towards the wall to slam
the ball against it. Catch the ball as it rebounds.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the ground, hip-width apart. Engage your core and press through your heels to lift your hips until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Hold the top position for 2-3 seconds, ensuring your glutes are fully engaged. Lower under control and repeat. Focus on squeezing your glutes at the top without overextending your lower back.

Step over a ball (or imaginary if none available) and as you plant your foot, keep it facing diagonally out to one side. Immediately bring the opposite foot through the ball to push it out into space 3-yards and accelerate out to follow it. Focus on good mechanics with hips opening into movements and bringing your centre-of-mass forwards while pushing off.

Stand with your back flat against a wall and lower into a 90-degree squat position, ensuring your knees are directly over your ankles. Maintain this static position and perform controlled heel raises, lifting your heels off the ground as high as possible, holding briefly at the top before lowering. Keep your weight balanced through the balls of your feet and avoid excessive rocking. Maintain even tension through your quads, calves and core throughout the exercise.
Stand tall with a slight bend in your knees, then lift one knee outward and upward, mimicking a fire hydrant movement. Maintain core stability and avoid excessive tilting. Repeat on the other side.

Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above the knees. Stand in an athletic position with your knees slightly bent and your hips back, maintaining tension on the band. Step diagonally forward and to the side with one foot, followed by the other forward to the opposite side, keeping the band taut throughout. Focus on controlled movements to activate your glutes and hip stabilisers.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart and raise one knee to hip height while keeping your foot dorsiflexed (toes up). In a smooth, controlled motion, move your raised leg outward, imagining clearing an invisible hurdle. Bring the leg back to the starting position and repeat on the other side. Avoid excessive hip rotation and maintain an upright torso throughout.

Start by turning 90 degrees and pushing off aggressively to sprint. To do  this, open the inside hip in the new direction and swing the back hip around the corner violently. While accelerating, perform a drop step or stutter step to load power before immediately bursting out in a new direction, generally 45 degrees to the left or right.
Step into a lunge with your back leg straight and heel planted. Gently press your hips forward until you feel a stretch in the back calf. Alternate legs in a flowing motion.

Find a moderate incline and position yourself at the base. Begin by sprinting up the hill at full effort, focusing on powerful knee drive and an aggressive forward lean. Keep your foot contacts quick and directly under your hips, ensuring that each stride drives you forward efficiently rather than reaching too far. Maintain a tall posture and active arm movement, using your upper body to generate momentum.

Start in an athletic stance, crossing one leg over the other in a sideways running motion, then quickly stepping the back leg behind. Maintain fluid hip rotation and fast footwork, keeping your upper body stable.

Start in a push-up position with your hands under your shoulders. Without bending your elbows, squeeze your shoulder blades together, lowering your chest slightly. Then, push through your hands and round your upper back as your shoulder blades spread apart.

Start in a half-kneeling position with your front foot flat and back knee on the ground. Lean forward slightly, keeping your chest up and core engaged. At the command, explosively drive off your front foot, pushing your back leg forward into a sprint. Focus on quick ground contact, knee drive and an aggressive first step to accelerate efficiently.

Exercise Name: Single Leg - RDL to A Position
Exercise Description: Perform a single-leg Romanian deadlift, hinging at the hips with a neutral spine. As you return to standing, lift your knee to hip height, pausing in an A-position. Maintain balance and control throughout.

Stand in front of a box or step with one foot planted on the surface and the other leg hovering behind you. Push forcefully through your front foot, driving your opposite knee up toward your chest as you extend your ankle, knee and hip into a bounding motion. Land softly on the same foot that was on the box, maintaining control and avoiding excessive forward lean. Reset and repeat on the same leg before switching sides.
Hold a dumbbell in one hand, keeping a neutral posture. Row the weight towards your ribcage, keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower under control. Avoid excessive twisting.

Start lying on the ground with feet flat on the floor and crossed arms above your head. Lift your upper body up and clear your shoulder blades off the ground, then hold and pause at the top for a second. Lower back down and then repeat immediately. The aim is to only lift your upper back and not lower in this movement. Complete 10 reps, take a
few seconds to recover, then repeat. Continue until you can no longer do this.

Stand sideways to a cable machine or anchored band at chest height. Grip the handle with both hands and step away from the anchor to create tension. Press the handle straight forward, extending your arms fully while keeping your core braced to resist rotation. From this position, rotate your torso towards the anchor in a controlled manner before returning to the centre and retracting the handle back to the chest.

Set two cones up 3 metres apart. Accelerate towards one cone then immediately turn out towards the opposite cone. Repeat between 2-4 times before finally extending beyond the cone a further two metres at full acceleration to finish.

Begin standing on one leg with your core engaged and your other leg slightly bent at the knee. Push off forcefully with your standing leg, hopping forward as far as you can while maintaining balance. As soon as you land, quickly hop again without pausing. Focus on keeping your hops powerful and continuous. After covering the desired distance, switch to the other leg and repeat. The goal is to improve unilateral power and stability, simulating the explosive single-leg actions required in sprinting.

Sit in a 90/90 hip position, with one knee bent in front at 90 degrees and the other behind at 90 degrees. Place a soft ball, pad or foam roller between your knees and squeeze to activate the adductors. Hold for the prescribed time.

Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight in front of you. Cross your right foot over your left thigh, placing your right foot flat on the floor next to your left knee. Place your right hand on the floor behind you for support and your left elbow outside your right knee. Sit tall, lengthening your spine, and gently twist your torso to the right. Hold briefly, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Lie flat on your back with arms extended to the sides for support. Raise your legs to 90 degrees, then rotate them side to side in a controlled motion, keeping your core engaged. Avoid excessive lower back movement.
Perform Split Stance Pogos, but moving laterally, maintaining rhythm and minimal ground contact time. Stay light on your feet and focus on reactivity.

Start in a split squat position with your feet staggered, front foot firmly planted and back knee slightly bent. From this position lift your front foot off the floor momentarily shifting your weight onto the back leg. Allow gravity to pull you downward and as you begin to drop place your front foot back on the ground and absorb the landing by bending through the front knee and sinking deeper into the split squat. Focus on controlling the descent ensuring a smooth force dissipation through the front leg rather than collapsing into the movement. Keep your torso upright, core engaged and knee tracking forward reinforcing eccentric control, landing mechanics and lower-body stability essential for deceleration in sprinting and multidirectional movements.
Sit or lie in a 90-degree knee position, placing a soft ball or foam roller between your knees. Squeeze the ball, holding the tension in your adductors, then release slightly before repeating.
Take exaggerated forward leaps, driving your knees high and swinging your arms. Focus on soft landings and explosive take-offs.

Stand in the middle of the trap bar with feet shoulder-width apart. Bend at your hips and knees while keeping your back straight and chest up. Grip the handles of the trap bar firmly, engage your core, and drive through your heels to lift the bar to a standing position. Lower the bar back down in a controlled manner. Progressively increase the weight to find your maximum lift.

Sit on a box or bench with your feet hanging just above the floor and knees at roughly 90 degrees. From this seated position, fall forwards until your feet touch the ground while swinging your arms and exploding upward to jump onto a box in front of you. Land softly with both feet fully on the box and absorb the landing through the hips. Step down and reset.

Stand facing a wall with your hands flat against it at shoulder height, leaning forward slightly so your body is at a 45-degree angle. Begin by driving one knee up toward your chest while keeping your opposite foot firmly planted. Alternate legs in a controlled marching motion, focusing on quick, powerful knee drives and maintaining a forward shin angle. Keep your torso stable, arms bent at 90 degrees and your core engaged throughout.

Sit on the floor with your upper back against a bench, positioning a resistance band around your hips and securing it under your feet. Drive through your heels, lifting your hips into a full bridge position and hold. Maintain tension in your glutes and core throughout.

Stand in front of a knee-high box or step. Begin by bounding forward off one foot, covering as much distance as possible while maintaining control. As you land, immediately step up explosively onto the box with the same foot, driving your opposite knee high. Reset and repeat all reps on one side before switching. Maintain rhythm, power, and control while focusing on a strong knee drive at the top of the movement.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart and hinge at your hips, reaching your hands towards the ground. Walk your hands forward into a plank position, ensuring your core stays engaged and your hips remain level. Hold briefly, then walk your hands back towards your feet, returning to a standing position without rushing.
Start in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other back. Jump explosively, switching your legs mid-air to land in the opposite lunge position. Focus on soft landings.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides and stand in front of a box or bench. Place one foot on the platform and push through your heel to drive your body upward as high as possible. As you rise, bring your opposite knee up towards your chest in a dynamic sprinting motion. Land softly before dropping the stepping leg back on the ground and resetting for the next rep

Start in a low athletic stance, with your feet hip-width apart and core engaged. Quickly perform short, rapid forward jab steps, ensuring your feet stay low to the ground and your weight remains balanced. Maintain a quick turnover while keeping your torso stable, avoiding excessive leaning.

Exercise Name: Bent Knee Abductions in Side Plank
Exercise Description: Start in a side plank position, supporting yourself on your forearm with your legs bent at 90 degrees. Lift your top knee upwards, keeping your feet together, then slowly return to the start. Focus on controlled movement and maintaining hip stability.

Stand tall in an athletic stance, leaning slightly forward with your arms bent at 90 degrees. Begin performing rapid, high-knee drives, focusing on quick turnover and keeping your knees at or above hip height. Your arms should swing naturally in coordination with the knee drive. At random intervals of 5-10 seconds, have a "stick" cue (verbal or visual e.g. using colours on your phone). Upon the cue, freeze immediately, holding the current position with one knee up, parallel to the ground and arms in proper sprint form. Maintain balance and control, engaging your core to stabilise the position. Hold for 2-3 seconds before resetting and resuming the knee drive.
Hold a dumbbell at each hip, keeping them close to your body. Pull them up towards your chin, leading with your elbows, then lower under control. Avoid excessive shrugging.

Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. Hinge at the hips and reach your hands to the ground. Walk your hands forward step by step until you are in a full plank position. Pause briefly, then walk the hands back towards the feet and return to standing. Keep the legs as straight as mobility allows and engage the core throughout the movement.

Stand on one leg with a slight bend in your knee, keeping your core engaged and posture upright. Imagine a clock face around you, then slowly reach one foot in different directions (forward, sideways and backward) while maintaining balance. Each time you extend your foot, control the movement before returning to the centre. Keep the stance leg engaged and avoid collapsing through the hip or knee.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell or kettlebell in each hand. Press the weights overhead until your arms are fully extended, with your palms facing forward and your biceps close to your ears. Engage your
core and keep your chest up and shoulders back, maintaining a neutral spine. Begin walking forward at a controlled pace while keeping the weights steady overhead. Continue walking for the desired distance, then carefully lower the weights back to the starting position. Turn around and repeat the next rep.

Sprint all out from a stand still. After covering the first 10 metres, bring your hands back to hold
them behind your head. Continue to sprint at the highest speed possible while maintaining a more upright position for the following 20 metres.
Stand tall, holding onto a support if needed. Lift your leg sideways, keeping it straight and controlled, then return under control. Can be done with a resistance band for added difficulty.

Begin jogging at a moderate pace, maintaining an upright posture and relaxed arm movement. When cued, decelerate rapidly, lowering into a controlled lunge position with your front knee tracking over your toes and your back knee hovering just above the ground. Absorb the landing through your front leg, ensuring a smooth and balanced transition before resuming the jog.

Begin sprinting at moderate intensity, then rapidly decelerate, lowering your centre of gravity while absorbing force through your quads and glutes. As you reach a controlled stop, plant your outside foot firmly and push off at an angle with a jab step, ensuring a strong lateral push-off while maintaining balance. Keep your core engaged and chest up, ensuring efficient force redirection.
Lie face down on the floor, engaging your glutes and hamstrings to lift your legs off the ground while keeping them straight. Hold briefly at the top before lowering under control.

Stand on a box or step, holding dumbbells at your sides. Slowly lower one foot toward the ground, bending the knee of your standing leg with control. Lightly touch the ground with your opposite foot, then push through your standing leg to return to the start position. Focus on a slow, controlled descent to reinforce eccentric strength.

Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell close to your chest in a goblet position. Stand with your feet wide apart, toes pointing slightly outward. Shift your weight to one side, bending your knee and lowering your hips into a deep lateral squat while keeping your opposite leg straight. Push through your bent leg to return to the starting position and alternate sides.

Position a barbell in the crease of your elbows, holding it securely against your chest with your forearms parallel to the floor. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your core engaged. Lower yourself into a squat by bending at the hips and knees, keeping your chest upright and elbows slightly forward. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.
Start in a prone plank position with feet in TRX straps. Engage your core, then drive your knees towards your chest in a controlled motion. Extend your legs back to starting position.

Kneel on a soft surface with your feet secured under a heavy object or partner assistance. Slowly lower your torso forward, keeping your body straight from knees to shoulders. Control the descent using your hamstrings, then push off lightly to return to the start.

Hold a dowel along your back, ensuring three points of contact (head, upper back, and tailbone). Hinge at the hips, pushing them back while maintaining a neutral spine. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to standing.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart, facing forward. Step sideways into a deep lateral lunge, lowering your hips while keeping your chest up. As you move, duck your torso under a hurdle or low bar, maintaining control and balance throughout the movement. Push through your outside leg to return to the starting position before repeating on the other side.

Set the cable at chest height and stand side-on to the machine. Balance on the leg furthest from the cable, holding the handle with both hands in front of your chest. Press the cable straight out and hold at full extension, resisting rotation. Return to the chest and repeat. Keep the standing leg stable and the core engaged to maintain alignment and control.

Stand in a split stance position with one foot forward and the other foot behind, ensuring your feet are about hip-width apart to maintain balance. Lower your back knee toward the ground until both knees reach approximately 90-degree angles, keeping your chest tall and core braced. Hold this position without allowing your front knee to collapse inward or extend too far forward past your toes. Maintain even weight distribution between your front heel and back toes, focusing on engaging the quads, glutes, and core to stabilise the position. Hold for the prescribed time before switching sides.

Start with feet shoulder-width apart and hold the barbell approximately 2 inches away from your shins. Push your hips
back and grab the barbell so your palms are facing your body and your hands are shoulder-width apart. Keep your hips down, chest lifted, eyes forward, and arms long. Keep your core tight and drive through your heels to pull the bar quickly up to your chest, just in front of your collarbone. Keep your spine tall. Be explosive and fast in your movement as you pull the bar, keeping it as close to your body as you can. To pull the bar underneath your shoulders, shrug your shoulders up and point your elbows forward. As soon as the bar reaches your chest, drive through your heels again, press the bar directly overhead and straighten your arms and legs. Keep your core tight. Return to the starting position with control.

Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place a weight barbell across your hips, holding it steady with your hands. Push through your heels to lift your hips until your body forms a straight line from your shoulders to your knees. Pause briefly at the top, then lower back down with control.

Place sliders under your feet or hands, depending on the exercise performed. Engage your core and move through controlled ranges of motion, maintaining stability and balance. Used in various exercises.

Step one foot forward into a lunge position, lowering your back knee toward the floor. While holding the lunge, twist your torso toward the front leg, engaging your core. Return to the starting position and alternate sides.

Hold heavy dumbbells or kettlebells in each hand, standing tall with your shoulders pulled back and core braced. Walk forward with short, controlled steps, keeping your grip strong and torso stable. Avoid excessive swaying or allowing the weights to pull your body out of alignment.

Exercise Name: Bent Knee Calf Raise - Off Step
Exercise Description: Stand on a raised surface with your heels hanging off the edge. Keeping your knees slightly bent, push through your forefoot to raise your heels upwards, then slowly lower back down below the step. Keep your movement smooth and controlled.

Stand with your back flat against a wall, feet about 6 inches away, and your lower back pressed firmly into the wall. Raise your arms to shoulder height with elbows bent at 90 degrees. Slowly slide your arms upward as if performing a snow angel, keeping your arms and hands in contact with the wall. Lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the ground. Place a light dumbbell across the top of your feet and lift your toes toward your shins, keeping your heels on the ground. Slowly lower back to the starting position.

Set the bar on a Smith machine at upper chest height and grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Dip slightly by bending the knees, then explode upward, using the legs to drive the bar overhead. Extend fully at the elbows at the top. Lower the bar under control to the shoulders and repeat, maintaining vertical posture and tight core engagement throughout.
Stand on one leg, bouncing lightly and rapidly, maintaining minimal ground contact time. Keep quick, controlled movements and focus on reactive strength. Switch legs after completing reps.

From the same start position, rotate your upper body away from the machine so that the cable extends across you. Maintain the same outstretched arms throughout the movement and do not
shift your lower body.
Stand on a step with your heels hanging off. Push up with both feet, then slowly lower your right heel below the step. Use your left leg to assist back up. Repeat on the opposite side.

Sprint forward for 20m at maximum speed. As you approach the deceleration point, lower your centre of gravity by bending your knees and hips, while hinging forwards at the hips. Pivot 180 degrees with some speed, then push off explosively through the first few steps.

Lay down flat on the floor. Hold a light dumbbell in one arm straight in the air above you. The movement is to rotate the dumbbell via your wrist so that it faces to the inside. Rotate back so that if faces forwards again. Continue with these rotations at increasing speeds if no pain is felt.

Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands on your hips to feel the movement. Tilt your pelvis forward, creating a small arch in your lower back (anterior tilt), then reverse the motion, flattening your lower back into the ground (posterior tilt). Focus on controlled movement and engaging the deep core muscles.

Stand with a slight forward lean and keep your core engaged. Perform quick, light foot taps, ensuring your toes stay just off the ground and your ankle remains stiff. The movement should be short and reactive, promoting efficient ground contact and proper sprint foot mechanics.

Using a squat rack or smith machine, place the barriers at knee height. Assume the starting deadlift position, hinging
from the hips with hands placed on the barbell just outside shoulder-width apart. As you pull upwards, the barrier will
prevent the bar from moving. Continue to pull with force for the desired duration, before dropping the bar and
releasing the tension.
Perform a glute bridge while squeezing a yoga block or medicine ball between your knees to engage the adductors and stabilise the pelvis. Hold the top position for 3 seconds.

Step one leg forward into a deep lunge. Push off the ground and bring your rear leg forward to step into the next lunge. Alternate legs
continuously, maintaining a steady rhythm.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and your core engaged. Step backward with one leg, lowering your back knee toward the ground while keeping your front shin vertical. Maintain an upright torso and avoid leaning forward. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position under control before switching sides.

Stand facing a wall and place your hands shoulder-width apart. Lean slightly forward and attach a resistance band around your waist or lower back. Drive one knee forward explosively, alternating legs, while keeping tension on the band.
Place a resistance band around your thighs. Step sideways, keeping tension on the band, and avoid dragging your feet. Stay in a slight squat position.

Set up an M-shape with cones (10m vertically, 5m horizontally in total - middle of the M 2.5m in). Sprint along the M itself from point to
point and then back to the start as fast as possible.

Start in a half-kneeling position with your front knee at a 90-degree angle and your back knee resting on the ground. Keep your torso upright and core engaged as you gently push your hips forward, feeling a stretch in the hip flexor of the back leg. Avoid arching your lower back by maintaining a neutral spine.

Set the treadmill incline to 10–12%. Begin by standing on the side rails and then step onto the moving belt at 80% of your sprinting speed. Drive your knees high, leaning slightly forward, and pump your arms aggressively. Focus on explosive, controlled strides during each sprint interval.
Sit on a bench and lift one knee up toward your chest, holding for 3 seconds before lowering. Alternate sides while keeping pelvic stability.
Stand facing a cable machine with the handles set at shoulder height. Pull the handles outward in a reverse fly motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Control the return and repeat.

Step forward into a lunge while simultaneously rotating your torso toward the front leg. Instead of stepping back to neutral, push through the front foot to bring the back leg forward, immediately stepping into another lunge on the opposite side. Maintain fluid motion and control throughout.

Lie on a bench with dumbbells in hand. Begin by rolling your shoulders back, lowering the dumbbells behind your head, then extend your arms fully back to the start position. Maintain controlled movement throughout.

Stand facing the sled, gripping the handles firmly with both hands. Lean slightly backward, keeping your torso upright and core engaged. Begin sprinting backward in a continuous motion, driving through your heels with powerful, explosive steps while maintaining constant tension on the sled. Keep your arms extended but active, ensuring a smooth pull without excessive upper-body movement. Focus on fast, forceful strides, avoiding any hesitation or pausing between steps.

Stand tall with a slight bend in your standing knee and your core engaged. Keeping your back straight, lift your opposite leg straight behind you, squeezing your glutes at the top while maintaining control. Avoid excessive arching of the lower back or swinging the leg. Lower back to the starting position under control before repeating on the same side.

Lie on your side with your elbow directly under your shoulder and legs stacked. Engage your core and lift your hips to form a straight line from head to feet. Reach your top arm under your torso, rotating through your thoracic spine, then return to the start position. Keep your hips stable and movement controlled throughout.

Step back into a deep lunge, lowering until your back knee nearly touches the ground. As you descend, rotate your torso towards the front leg while maintaining an upright posture. Return to the starting position by pushing through the front foot and resetting your torso to face forward before switching sides.

Hang from a bar above your head a couple of feet off the ground. Let go of the bar and then jump vertically immediately upon touching the ground. Spend as little time as possible on the ground. Grab the bar again to reset for the next rep. Keep your body upright with only a small bend in the knees at the point of the jump.

Hold a barbell overhead with a wide grip, ensuring your elbows remain locked out and core engaged. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then hinge at the hips by pushing them back while keeping your spine neutral. Lower your torso forward until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to standing by driving your hips forward. Maintain full-body tension throughout to avoid excessive back arching.

Stand on a box around knee height. Step off the box and absorb the landing by bending at the hips and knees while maintaining an upright torso. The moment your feet contact the ground, explode laterally to the side. Reset and repeat.

Lie on your back with your feet flat and knees bent, lifting your hips into a glute bridge position. Keeping your core engaged and hips stable, lift one knee towards your chest, then lower it back down and repeat on the other side. Focus on maintaining hip alignment and avoiding excessive movement in the lower back.

Lie flat on your back with one leg raised at 90 degrees and the other extended just above the floor. Engage your core and hip flexors, keeping the raised leg stable while resisting rotation. Ensure your lower back remains in contact with the ground. Hold for the prescribed time before switching sides.

Anchor a resistance band or cable at chest height. Stand perpendicular to the anchor point, gripping the handle with both hands at your chest. Step away to create tension in the band, keeping your feet shoulder-width apart. Press your hands straight out in front of you, resisting the rotational pull from the band. Hold briefly before returning to the start position.

Hop laterally off one foot towards the direction of the opposite foot and land on this opposite foot. Hold momentarily in a sprint position with one knee raised and a neutral balanced centre-of-mass. Then fall forward into a 5m acceleration. Apply maximal effort across these initial steps.

Set up a grid with clear lines connecting them, creating a path for movement - 25x25m with 5m cone intervals. Both the main player ("Pacman") and the opponent must stay on the cone line during the drill. Pacman’s objective is to evade the opponent while moving along the cone lines and they can only change direction at a cone. The opponent must react to Pacman’s movements, following the same rules—no cutting corners or crossing lines. The drill continues until Pacman is tagged or after a set time (e.g. 30 seconds). Reset and rotate roles for the next round.

Start in a quadruped position with your hands directly under your shoulders and knees hovering just above the ground. Keeping your core engaged and hips low, lift one hand off the floor while rotating your torso and extending the opposite leg underneath your body toward the opposite side. As you reach the end position, your hip should be close to the ground and your chest should remain open. Return to the starting position with control and repeat on the other side.
Walk forward on the balls of your feet, keeping your heels elevated. Take small steps and maintain balance throughout.

Start in a sprint-ready stance, then accelerate forward for a short burst (5-10m). At a designated marker or verbal cue, plant your foot and change direction explosively, pushing off the outside leg and driving the opposite knee forward. Keep your torso controlled and hips low to maintain balance during the turn.

Sit with your legs extended and place a soft ball, pad or foam roller between your ankles. Squeeze the object firmly, engaging your inner thighs, and hold for the prescribed time. Maintain a neutral posture throughout.

Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground, hip-width apart. Place the resistance band just above the knees and keep slight tension throughout the movement. Engage your core and glutes, pushing through your heels to lift your hips. Hold briefly at the top, then lower back down slowly.

Secure your feet in a GHD (Glute-Ham Developer) machine, keeping your hips positioned at the pad's edge. Lower under control, then engage your glutes and hamstrings to raise yourself back to parallel.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand, hinge slightly forward, and keep your elbows at your sides. Extend your arms fully behind you, squeezing your triceps, then return under control.

Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet wider than hip-width. Rock your knees to one side, letting both legs fall into a 90/90 position. Lean into the front leg slightly to deepen the stretch, then rotate back through centre and switch to the opposite side. Use your hips to guide the movement and keep the spine tall throughout. The focus is on internal and external hip rotation through controlled motion.

Stand facing a wall with your hands placed shoulder-width apart at chest height. Lean forward so your body forms a straight line from head to heels. Drive one knee up explosively, then alternate exploding the opposite knee up with a pause at the end of each motion. Keep your toes dorsiflexed and maintain constant pressure against the wall.

Begin in an athletic stance. Perform two powerful horizontal bounds from one leg to the other, covering distance with each stride. After the second bound, immediately transition into a short sprint of 5 to 10 metres. Focus on smooth transitions and aggressive acceleration out of the final bound. Stay low and drive forward during the sprint phase.
Hold a barbell or dumbbells with an overhand grip. Curl the weight towards your shoulders, keeping your wrists neutral. Lower under control and repeat. Focus on forearm engagement.

Stand facing a wall in a forward lean with both palms pressed into it at shoulder height. Position one foot forward and one back, knees slightly bent. Actively drive your hands into the wall as hard as possible, bracing through the core and pushing through your back leg. Maintain full tension throughout your body for the duration of the hold, focusing on posture, force intent and ankle stiffness.

Exercise Name:
Hanging Vertical Jump	Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Engage your core, then  release your grip to fall towards the ground. Upon landing, absorb the force with a slight bend through the knees and immediately jump as high as possible, grabbing onto the bar to return to the original position. Aim for minimal ground contact time.	5	3	-	90s
Depth Jump into Box Jump	Stand on a low box (cc 20"). Step off, landing softly on the ground with knees bent. Load up into a jump onto the highest box possible.
Sets:
20" - Highest Possible	90s
Lateral Hop into Elevated Push-Off Jump	Stand beside a low box. Perform a lateral hop toward the box, then immediately explode upward onto the box, landing with both feet in a neutral stance. Immediately leap forwards as far as possible from the box. Aim to stick the subsequent landing on the ground, but most importantly take care to not let one side overcompensate for the other in controlling the force.	8 (4 each side)	3	20"

Exercise Description: Start in a high plank position with a dumbbell in each hand, keeping your core engaged and feet shoulder-width apart for stability. Row one dumbbell toward your ribs, keeping your elbow close to your body while avoiding excessive rotation. Lower the weight under control and repeat on the other side.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart, holding a weight plate at chest height. Keeping your core braced, move the plate in a circular motion around your head, ensuring smooth and controlled movement. Complete all reps in one direction before switching sides. Avoid excessive swaying and keep your hips and shoulders stable throughout.
Stand facing a wall or sturdy object for support. Step one foot back and press your heel into the ground while bending your front knee. Push forward gently and then release.

Stand sideways to a cable machine, gripping the handle at shoulder height. Rotate your torso downward, pulling the handle diagonally towards your opposite hip. Control the return and repeat. Keep your feet planted.

Stand to the side of a cable machine so that you are facing parallel to it rather than directly
towards or away. Clutch a handle in both hands outstretched in front of you. Take a step to the
side and away from the machine to place this under tension. The movement is then to keep both arms straight while raising the cable up above your head in a circular motion.

Start in an athletic stance. Bound diagonally off one foot, travelling forward and laterally. Land on both feet simultaneously in a low, balanced position, absorbing the force through the hips and holding the landing briefly to show control. Reset and repeat in the opposite direction. Focus on explosive take-off, soft and stable landings and maintaining chest height throughout.

Exercise Name:
Lateral Band Walks
with Toe Tap
Exercise Description:
Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above the knees.
Maintain a slight squat and step laterally, keeping tension on the band.
After each step, tap your toe to the ground before stepping again.

Exercise Name: Bent Knee & Straight Leg Wall Pushes
Exercise Description: Stand facing a wall with both hands pressed against it at shoulder height. For the bent knee variation, push through your forefoot, keeping your knee bent at 90 degrees. For the straight leg variation, extend your leg fully and push through the ball of your foot. Maintain control and tension, ensuring a strong calf contraction.

Start by gripping the pull-up bar with an overhand grip, keeping your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and lats, then pull yourself upwards, driving your elbows down and back while keeping your chest lifted towards the bar. As you approach the top of the pull-up, simultaneously lift your knees towards your chest, engaging your core and hip flexors. Hold briefly at the top before lowering yourself under control, ensuring your legs return to a straight position before the next rep. Maintain a tight, controlled movement throughout, avoiding excessive swinging or momentum.

Attach a light resistance band firmly to any fence, pole or rooted object. Step inside the band and move away from it diagonally until light flex on the band. Start by accelerating out in the same diagonal direction putting the band under much stronger flexion. As it reaches its maximum resistance, shift roughly 90° utilising the force of the band to help propel you faster out in the new direction. Continue until light flex in the new direction and then decelerate to reset.

Lie on your side with legs extended and feet stacked. Place your elbow directly under your shoulder and forearm flat on the ground. Lift your hips off the floor to form a straight line from head to feet. Hold this position, keeping hips square and core braced. Avoid sagging at the hips or rolling forward/backward. Maintain steady breathing throughout the hold.

Using a Keiser machine, set yourself up in a squatted position with pads on either shoulder, or cables in each hand clutched tight to your chest (depending on the machine). Ideally, between a squat and half-squat position with your quads slightly above parallel to the ground. Do not start from a deep squat position though as the aforementioned range of motion is all we are looking for. From this position, quickly drop a couple of inches from the hips before immediately driving vertically upwards as powerfully as possible.

On the SkiErg machine, stand with your feet shoulder width apart and a slight bend at the knees. Grab each handle in the corresponding hand and pull out slightly for tension. Aggressively ski each handle down to your waist before quickly returning to the start position to repeat. Complete at the fastest speed possible while showing maximum
intent with each ski.

Stand tall and step laterally with one foot. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest upright, and open your hips to that side. Push through your heels to return to standing and repeat on the opposite side.

Begin moving forward, backward or laterally at a controlled pace. A coach or partner will call out “stop” at random intervals, requiring you to decelerate immediately into a stable position. Keep your knees bent, core engaged and weight balanced to avoid stumbling.

Lie on your side with your legs extended and your top leg straight. Keep your core engaged and lift your top leg upwards, maintaining a controlled motion without rotating your hips. Lower it slowly back down and repeat. Ensure the movement comes from the hip rather than the lower back.

Stand tall with your arms extended at your sides. Swing both arms forward across your chest in a hugging motion, then open them wide again behind your body. Continue alternating swings in a rhythmic fashion, crossing one arm over the other on each rep. Maintain a relaxed posture and allow your shoulders to move freely. This is a light dynamic movement used to activate the upper body.

Start in a low athletic stance with your dominant foot slightly behind your lead foot. Explode forward using your arms to drive momentum, focusing on powerful strides pushing through the ground for the first few steps. Transition into longer strides as you complete the 10m distance. Walk back to recover before the next sprint.

Lie on your side with your lower leg bent at 90 degrees, resting on your forearm. Place your top leg on a bench and lift your hips off the ground, engaging your adductors and core. Hold for the prescribed time before switching sides.

Stand tall with your feet shoulder-width apart. Reach your arms straight
up towards the ceiling, then lower into a deep squat while keeping your
chest upright and arms overhead. Push through your heels to return to
standing, maintaining an extended spine throughout the movement.

Hold a medicine ball to your chest. Drop your hips backwards towards the ground and then immediately jump
vertically. Land from one rep and go straight into the next. For the final rep, launch the ball vertically above your head as far as possible – be careful when catching it or getting out of the way as it falls.

Assume a low, athletic position with your knees bent and your chest upright, leaning back slightly into the sled. Drive through your heels, extending your legs forcefully with each step as you walk backward. Maintain a steady pace and ensure the sled moves smoothly without jerking.
Perform Split Stance Pogos, but moving backwards, keeping quick, controlled movements and maintaining reactive strength.

Stand over a barbell with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly outward and one foot in front of the barbell, the other behind. Grip the barbell with each hand. Begin the lift by pushing through your heels and extending your hips, keeping your back flat and core engaged. Stand  upright with the barbell, then lower it back to the ground with control.
Assume a push-up position with hands close together, keeping your elbows tucked. Lower your chest to the floor, then push back up, maintaining a straight body line. Focus on triceps activation.

Hold a kettlebell close to your chest in a goblet position. Stand with feet slightly wider than hip-width and toes turned out slightly. Drop into a squat by sitting the hips back and down, keeping the chest tall and elbows inside the knees. Drive through the heels to return to standing. Keep the kettlebell stable and close to your body throughout the movement.

Exercise Name: Side Lying Hip Abd + Int Rotation
Exercise Description: Lie on your side with your lower leg bent and your top leg extended. Lift your top leg upwards, then rotate your foot internally before returning to the start. Maintain control throughout.

Start by marching in place, driving your knee up to waist height while keeping your toe dorsiflexed (toes up). As your knee reaches its highest point, extend your leg forward before snapping it back down to the ground with a quick, reactive step. Maintain a tall posture, controlled arm movement, and active ground contacts, ensuring an efficient stride rhythm.

Lie on your back with your legs straight and place a soft ball, pad or foam roller between your lower legs (near ankles). Squeeze the object tightly, engaging your inner thighs, then relax and repeat.

Kneel on both knees sideways to a cable machine or resistance band anchor at chest height. Hold the handle or band with both hands and press it straight out in front of your chest. Keeping your core tight and resisting rotation, slowly twist your torso away from the anchor before returning to the centre. Control the movement and avoid excessive hip or shoulder rotation.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball overhead with both hands. Engage your core and
keep your chest up. In one explosive motion, slam the ball down towards the ground as hard as you can, using your
whole body to generate power. Allow your knees to bend slightly as you slam the ball to absorb the impact. Catch the
ball on the bounce and immediately repeat the movement. Focus on generating maximum power with each slam,
using your core, arms, and legs to drive the motion.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Place a soft medicine ball or foam roller between your knees. Drive through your heels to lift your hips off the ground into a glute bridge while squeezing the object firmly between your knees. Hold briefly at the top, then lower under control. Focus on engaging both the glutes and inner thighs throughout the movement.
Stand on one leg with your eyes closed. Keep your knee slightly bent and focus on maintaining a strong neutral balance resisting all motion.

Begin in a full plank with hands under shoulders and feet hip-width apart. While keeping your hips square, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. Lower it back down and repeat on the other side. Continue alternating taps without shifting your weight excessively. Engage the core to prevent rotation and maintain a steady base.

Stand side-on to the starting line with your body facing 90 degrees away from the sprint direction. Take a powerful crossover step with your outside leg, pivoting your hips to face forward as you drive into a sprint. Focus on quick foot placement and strong arm drive to maximise acceleration.

Position yourself in front of a wall with your hands pressed against it, leaning slightly forward at a 45-degree angle. Lift one knee toward your waist level, ensuring your toes are dorsiflexed (pointed up) and your ankle stays under the knee. Lower the leg under control while simultaneously lifting the opposite knee in a slow, rhythmic marching pattern. Maintain a tall posture, active core engagement and proper hip positioning throughout. The movement should be smooth and deliberate, reinforcing proper foot placement and sprint mechanics.
Hold a barbell with a shoulder-width grip, keeping the bar close to your body. Pull it up towards your chin, leading with your elbows, then lower under control. Avoid excessive shrugging.

Start kneeling on a soft surface with your toes pointing back and hands behind you. Swing your arms forward as you explosively jump from the kneeling position to land on your feet in a squat stance. Immediately hop laterally to one side, landing softly with control. Reset back to the kneeling position and repeat, alternating sides.

Start tall on your toes with your arms pointed directly upwards overhead. Drop quickly towards the ground and absorb the force in a half-squat. As soon as you stabilise, push off forcefully to the side, leaping laterally to cover distance. Land softly, maintaining control before resetting for the next rep.

Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and a dumbbell placed between them. Hinge at the hips to grip the dumbbell with one hand, keeping your chest up and back flat. Drive forcefully through the legs and hips to lift the dumbbell in one explosive motion. As it rises past chest height, rotate your arm and punch the weight overhead, locking out at full extension. Lower with control and repeat on the other side. Keep the movement crisp and driven by lower-body power.

Hold the end of a barbell in a landmine attachment with both hands at chest height. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. As you return to standing, press the bar upward and slightly forward, fully extending your arms. Lower the bar back to chest height and repeat.

Step into a deep lunge position with one foot forward and the opposite leg extended back. Place both hands on the ground inside your front foot. Rotate your torso, reaching one arm towards the sky, then return your hand to the floor. Switch sides.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then stagger your stance by placing your back foot slightly behind you, keeping only the toe of your back foot on the ground for balance. The majority of your weight should be on your front leg, with your back leg providing minimal support. Maintain a neutral spine and a slight bend in your front knee. Begin the movement by hinging at your hips, pushing them backwards while lowering your torso forward. Keep the weight close to your body (if holding a dumbbell, kettlebell, or barbell) and ensure that your shoulders remain pulled back. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then drive through your front heel to return to standing. Keep the movement controlled and ensure the front leg remains the primary driver while the back leg offers light support.

Start with feet shoulder-width apart. Perform three consecutive jumps, taking off and landing with both feet each time. Focus on maximising horizontal distance with each jump while maintaining control.

Standing on one leg on top of a 20kg weight plate, lift your alternate knee up to waist height. At the same time, have one arm down to your side and the other out in front of you in a sprinting position. As you then drop down to place your weight on the opposite foot on the floor, alternate your arms and bring your other knee up to waist height following the sprinting motion. The aim is to spend as little time on the floor as possible before returning to the starting position on the weight for 1 rep.
Start in an athletic stance, then jump explosively while rotating your torso mid-air. Land softly and controlled, immediately repeating in the opposite direction. Keep your core engaged throughout.

Lie on your back with legs raised and knees slightly bent. Slowly lower your legs towards the floor, maintaining core engagement. Control the movement without arching your back. Return to the start and repeat.

Stand inside a trap bar with your feet shoulder-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Grip the handles firmly and lift the bar into a
standing position. Lower yourself into a partial squat, then explosively jump upwards, lifting the bar off the ground. Land softly, reset, and repeat. Ensure the movement is smooth and controlled without excessive impact on landing.
Perform a Nordic hamstring curl while holding a weight plate at your chest to increase resistance. Lower under control, then return to the start without losing core engagement.

Start with your toes over the edge of the box and your arms raised above your head to stretch as tall as possible. Step
off the box and allow gravity to take you down towards the ground. Land on both feet and immediately jump vertically as quickly as possible. You should then land in a controlled squat position to dissipate your force into the ground.

Stand perpendicular to a cable machine with the handle attached to the low pulley. Hold the handle with both hands at hip height and step away from the machine to create tension. Rotate your torso and hips towards the machine, pivoting on your outside foot to add more twist to the movement. Then, quickly rotate away from the machine, switching your grip mid-swing, and punch the handle forward (away from the machine) as you finish the rotation, fully extending your arms. Control the return as you rotate back to the starting position, keeping tension on the cable and maintaining a strong core.

Hang from a pull-up bar with a shoulder-width grip, engaging your core and lats to prevent excessive swinging. Keeping your legs together, drive your knees upward toward your chest, then twist your hips to one side at the top of the movement. Lower under control before repeating on the opposite side. Focus on controlled movement and avoid excessive momentum.

Begin in a bear crawl position with hands under shoulders and knees bent at 90 degrees, hovering a few centimetres off the floor. Hold this iso position with core braced and back flat. From here, lift one hand and tap the opposite knee lightly without shifting hips or letting the torso rotate. Return the hand to the ground and repeat on the other side, alternating taps while maintaining full-body stability.

Lie flat on a bench with your feet firmly planted on the ground and your eyes positioned directly under the barbell. Grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Retract your shoulder blades, arch your lower back slightly, and keep your core tight. Unrack the bar and slowly lower it to your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the bar back up explosively to the starting position, fully extending your arms while avoiding locking out your elbows. Focus on squeezing your chest and engaging your triceps at the top of the movement.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart, keeping your core engaged. Slowly rise onto your toes, lifting your heels as high as possible, then lower back down under control. Ensure a smooth movement, avoiding excessive rocking or bouncing at the top. For added resistance, perform the exercise holding a weight or on a raised surface for an increased range of motion.

Use an overspeed training device such as a long resistance band to assist in vertical jumps. Attach the bands to a
sturdy anchor point above you, and secure them around your waist or shoulders. Stand with your feet shoulder-width
apart and engage your core. Perform a quick dip by bending your knees and hips, then explode upwards into a vertical
jump, using the assistance from the bands to help you achieve maximum height. Land softly on the balls of your feet,
immediately bending your knees to absorb the impact. Repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions, focusing on
maintaining a powerful and controlled movement throughout.

Start in an athletic stance. Push off one leg and bound diagonally forward and to the side, landing softly on the opposite foot. Stick the landing by lowering slightly into the hip and holding for a count to show control. Keep the chest up and arms active to assist balance. Alternate bounds, maintaining forceful push-offs and balanced, quiet landings with each rep.

Begin in a half-kneeling position with one foot forward and the back knee on the floor. Tuck the pelvis under slightly and shift the hips forward into a deep stretch through the rear hip flexor. Reach the same-side arm as the rear leg overhead and diagonally across the body. Hold the end range for a moment before returning to the start. Avoid arching the lower back -

Lie on your side with knees bent at 90 degrees and feet stacked. Keeping your feet together, lift your top knee upwards, then slowly lower it back down. Keep your hips stable and avoid rolling back. Add a resistance band for extra difficulty.

Stand in an athletic stance, with a resistance band anchored to one side at waist height. Hold the band with both hands at your chest, ensuring your hips and shoulders remain square. Without rotating, brace your core and resist the band’s pull, holding a stable position for the required time. Keep your knees slightly bent and weight evenly distributed.

Sit upright with hands on your shoulders. Rotate your torso to one side as far as possible, then return to centre. Repeat to the other side. Focus on initiating movement through your mid-back rather than your lower back.

Exercise Name: Stationary Hip Turn + 90° Step-Out to Sprint
Exercise Description: Turn one hip out to the side, then with the corresponding foot, take a short step out to that side. Immediately, whip the back hip around the corner and push off into a 5m acceleration with full effort. Aim to build this up from initially slow transitions between each action into one fluid motion.
Stand tall, holding a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbell overhead until fully extended, keeping your core engaged. Lower under control before switching sides.

Stand with your back against a wall and slide down until your knees are bent at a 90-degree angle. Keep your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart, and hold this position. Ensure your back stays pressed against the wall and your core remains engaged.

Set up the barbell on the rack on safety pins, so that the barbell sits just below the knee. Approach the barbell with a hip width stance as if standing ready to take a jump straight up in the air. Push your hips back and bend your knees slightly to grip the bar just outside of hip width, next to your shins. Lift your chest, roll your shoulder blades back. Drive through both feet, imagining pushing the ground away from you. As the bar rises, push your hips forward and squeeze the glutes and hamstrings as you reach full lock out of the hips. Use your back muscles to keep the barbell as close to your legs as possible throughout the lift. To reverse the pull, maintain your neutral spine with the shoulder blades pinned back before pushing your hips back and hinging until the barbell is resting safety pins again.

Hold a handle connected to a cable machine out in front of your body, maintaining it at shoulder-height. Move laterally to the machine so that the cable is under tension. Step laterally away from the machine while maintaining this position and bracing your core. Take three short steps, leading off
your front foot and following with your back. Then, repeat in the opposite direction, moving back towards the machine to complete 1 rep.

Stand tall on your tip-toes with you arms extended overhead. Allow yourself to fall forwards with gravity naturally taking you towards the ground. Allow your instinct to take the step forwards preventing your fall, finishing in a nice, controlled lunge position.

Stand in front of a box or step, placing your lead foot diagonally across the platform. Drive through your foot, stepping up and bringing your opposite knee up to hip height. Lower under control before switching sides.

Start by gripping parallel dip bars with your arms locked out and your body suspended above the ground. If using added weight, secure a weight plate with a dip belt or hold a dumbbell between your legs. Lower your body under control by bending your elbows to approximately 90 degrees, keeping your chest slightly forward and shoulders down. Push explosively back to the starting position by extending your elbows fully while maintaining core engagement and proper shoulder positioning. Avoid excessive forward leaning or flaring your elbows too wide.

Stand tall with your core engaged. Bounce quickly and lightly on the balls of your feet, switching from one foot to the other while keeping minimal ground contact time. Focus on reactive, explosive movements while maintaining a steady rhythm.

Adjust the seat height so that your knees are slightly bent at the bottom
of the pedal stroke. Set the resistance to 30% of the max. Grip the
handlebars firmly and start pedalling as fast as possible while pushing
and pulling with your arms. Aim for maximum effort during the sprint.
Use controlled breathing to recover during the rest periods.

Begin in a tall standing position, with your feet hip-width apart and your weight slightly forward. At the cue, explosively drive off your back foot, pushing your knee forward and accelerating into a full sprint. Maintain a strong arm drive and an aggressive forward lean in the first few strides before transitioning into an upright sprint posture.
Perform the same movement as the barbell variation, but with dumbbells, allowing for greater range of motion and reducing strain on the wrists. Keep control throughout.

Exercise Name: March to Decel with Drop - Band-Assisted
Exercise Description: Attach a resistance band to a low anchor and loop it around your waist. Start in a marching pattern, driving your knees high while maintaining an upright torso and dorsiflexed ankles. At the command, quickly drop into a low deceleration stance, absorbing the force through your glutes and quads while keeping your knees stable and chest up. The band provides resistance and assistance, reinforcing controlled deceleration and posture.

Exercise Name: Incline Dumbbell Overhead Press Feet Up
Exercise Description: Perform the Incline DB Overhead Press, but with your feet lifted off the ground, engaging your core for added stability. Keep your back flat against the bench.

Stand tall in an athletic position with your feet hip-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Lean slightly forward from the hips, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. Drive one foot back slightly into a staggered stance so you are ready to push off explosively. Focus on generating maximum force through the lead leg. From this position, take a single, powerful step forward as far as you can, extending fully through your hip, knee, and ankle to generate force. Swing your opposite arm aggressively to counterbalance and maximise power. As soon as your foot lands, decelerate by planting firmly and lowering your hips to control the forward momentum. Reset to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, alternating your lead leg.

Set a cable machine to a high pulley position. Stand perpendicular to the machine and grip the handle with both hands. Pull the cable diagonally downward across your body, rotating your torso while keeping your arms extended. Pivot your back foot to allow for full rotation. Return to the starting position with control and repeat on the opposite side.

Hold a barbell with an underhand grip, keeping your elbows tucked close to your sides. Curl the bar up towards your chest, maintaining a controlled movement and avoiding swinging. Lower it slowly back down.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and hands placed on your hips or at your sides for balance. Shift your weight slightly onto one leg while lifting the opposite knee to about hip height. From this position, draw a large, controlled circular motion with your lifted knee, moving outward and then downward before bringing it back to the starting position. Reverse the movement after completing all reps in one direction. Keep your core engaged, and ensure your hips remain square to the front without excessive torso movement.

Begin in an athletic stance, leaning slightly forward with your knees bent and weight on the balls of your feet. Drive forward into the 10m build-up phase, gradually increasing your speed to approximately 80-90% of your maximum effort. Focus on short, powerful strides during the build-up while keeping your torso low and arms driving naturally. As you transition into the 10m hold phase, maintain this high-speed pace with consistent stride mechanics, keeping your posture upright and your core engaged. Aim to stabilise your rhythm, with controlled arm swings and efficient foot contact under your hips. In the final 10m acceleration phase, push explosively off the ground to increase your speed beyond the hold pace, driving your knees higher and extending your stride length. Keep your upper body relaxed and maintain powerful arm swings. Gradually decelerate after completing the sprint to avoid unnecessary strain. Walk back to the start to recover fully before repeating.

Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders and feet shoulder-width apart. While keeping your core engaged, lift one arm and reach forward. Pause briefly, then return the arm to the floor. Alternate sides, ensuring your hips remain level throughout.

Start from a static squat position, knees bent at a 90-degree angle. Engage your core and explosively jump vertically as high as you can. Land softly, returning to the squat position. Measure the jump height or use video footage for analysis.

Stand tall with feet wider than shoulder-width and one foot on a slider. Slowly slide the foot outward while keeping the other leg slightly bent and planted. Lower your hips into a lateral lunge as the slider leg extends fully. Pause briefly, then pull the slider leg back in using your inner thigh muscles. Keep the torso upright and the movement controlled throughout.

Start with your toes over the edge of the box and your arms raised above your head to stretch as tall as possible. Step
off the box and allow gravity to take you down towards the ground. Land on both feet and immediately jump vertically as quickly as possible. As you land, immediately launch as far forwards as possible off both feet.

Sit on the floor with your upper back resting against a bench and a barbell positioned over your hips. Drive through your heels to lift your hips until your thighs and torso form a straight line. Squeeze your glutes at the top, then lower back down with control.

Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Press through your heels to lift your hips into a glute bridge. From this position, slowly walk your feet out one small step at a time while keeping hips elevated. Once at your maximum controlled distance, walk the feet back in. Do not let the hips sag during the walkout. Maintain glute and core engagement throughout.
While seated, lift only your big toe while keeping the smaller toes flat, then reverse by lifting your smaller toes while keeping your big toe flat.

Lie flat on your back with your knees bent at 90 degrees and arms extended straight above your shoulders. Engage your core by pressing your lower back into the floor ensuring no arching occurs. Slowly lower one arm and the opposite leg toward the ground simultaneously keeping both straight and moving with control. Stop just before your lower back loses contact with the floor then return to the starting position and switch sides. Maintain steady breathing and core tension throughout the movement.

Stand tall with feet hip-width apart and arms by your sides. Lift one knee towards your chest while driving the opposite arm forward. Lower that leg and repeat on the other side, marching in place with an exaggerated knee lift and strong arm swing. Maintain posture and rhythm, focusing on quick foot contacts and coordinated movement.

Exercise Name: World’s Greatest Stretch with Lunge Hold + Rotation
Exercise Description: Step forward into a long lunge and place both hands on the floor inside the front foot. Keep the back leg straight and hips low. Rotate your torso and reach the inside arm up towards the ceiling, opening through the chest. Hold the lunge and rotation briefly before returning the hand to the ground. Step back and repeat on the other side. Keep tension through the hips and length through the spine as you move.
Hold a landmine barbell in one hand and step forward into a deep lunge, keeping the weight close to your body. Push back up to the start position, maintaining a stable core. Alternate sides each rep.
Hold gymnastic rings and lean back with your body in a straight line. Pull your chest towards the rings, keeping your elbows close to your sides. Lower under control and repeat.

Perform the Harop Curl, but focus on keeping tension in the upper part of your hamstrings by engaging them earlier in the descent. Maintain a slower eccentric phase for greater proximal hamstring activation. Return to the start with control.

Stand facing lateral to a  wall, holding a medicine ball at chest height with both hands. Engage your core and hips, then rotate through your trailing foot, hips and torso, generating maximum rotational force. Explosively throw the ball against the wall, aiming for maximum power. The arms follow the movement, but the torso and legs generate the force. Catch the ball on the rebound and reset before the next rep.

Stand tall with a slight forward lean, keeping your core engaged and ankles stiff. Rapidly tap the ground with quick, light contacts, bringing your knees only slightly above shin level. Keep your foot placement directly under your hips, maintaining a fast and controlled rhythm. Avoid excessive vertical movement and ensure a consistent turnover.

Hold a battle rope in each hand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and engage your core. Begin creating
alternating waves by moving your arms up and down rapidly. Focus on maintaining consistent intensity while keeping your upper body stable.
Perform a crossover step, then immediately return to a balanced, athletic stance. Keep your weight centred and ensure quick, controlled movement. Maintain low positioning throughout.

Kneel on the floor with hips aligned over your knees and hold a weight plate with both hands at hip height. Keeping your core engaged and back straight, slowly raise the plate overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower under control to the starting position. Avoid arching your lower back and focus on keeping the movement smooth and controlled throughout.
Perform a Nordic hamstring curl, but stop at mid-range, then push back up before completing the full descent. Engage your glutes and hamstrings throughout to control the movement.

Stand tall with your feet together. Hop vertically, keeping your knees
straight and using your ankles and calves to generate the movement.
Focus on quick, rhythmic bounces.

Begin in a standard push-up position, with your hands shoulder-width apart and your body forming a straight line from head to heels. Lower your chest toward the floor, keeping your elbows tucked at a 45-degree angle. Push up explosively, generating enough force for your hands to leave the ground. Clap your hands together in mid-air, then land softly with bent elbows and immediately transition into the next rep. Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and engaging your core throughout.
Stand on the balls of your feet and hold the top position of a calf raise. Keep your ankles stable and core engaged throughout the hold.

Set a line of low hurdles or cones in front of you. Step over each hurdle one at a time by lifting the lead knee high and driving it forward while keeping the torso upright. Clear the hurdle without rotating your hips or leaning to the side, then follow through with the trail leg in a smooth motion. Continue through the sequence with controlled and deliberate steps. Maintain balance and posture throughout. Without any equipment simply imagine hip-height hurdles to step over.

Exercise Name: Hip Hinge to Fall into Wall
Exercise Description: Stand upright with a slight forward lean. Hinge at the hips while keeping your core engaged. As you hinge further, allow yourself to fall forward slightly and catch yourself against a wall. Reset and repeat.

Kneel sideways to a cable machine, gripping the handle with both hands at shoulder height. Rotate your torso downward, pulling the handle diagonally towards your opposite hip. Control the return and repeat.

Start on all fours with knees under hips and hands under shoulders. Lift one knee off the floor and move it in a wide circular motion - first drawing the knee towards your chest, then out to the side, then up and around behind you. Reverse the motion to return. Move slowly and under full control to isolate the hip joint. Keep the rest of your body stable and avoid twisting the spine or shifting weight.

Hold a barbell in the front rack position, assume a wide sumo stance, and lower into a deep squat. Drive through your heels, keeping your core engaged to return to standing. Maintain torso stability throughout.

Start in a split squat position, holding a medicine ball at chest height. Lift your front foot slightly off the ground, then allow gravity to drop you into a deeper lunge as your front foot lands. As you absorb the landing, maintain control through your core and legs, ensuring the ball stays steady without excessive movement.

Mark out a 10m lane with cones at 5m intervals. Start in an athletic stance and sprint forward to the third cone (10m). Decelerate quickly by lowering your centre of gravity, then transition into a backpedal to the second cone (5m). At the second cone, turn 180 degrees and accelerate into a sprint toward the first cone.

Start in a kneeling or standing position, gripping an ab roller or barbell. Roll forwards under control, keeping your core braced and avoiding excessive lower back arching. Return to the start using core strength.

Start in a press-up position with both knees on the ground, close to and facing in towards a wall. From this position, raise your knees slightly off the ground so that your shins still face towards the ground but your knees do not support your weight at all. Start by walking each hand one at a time, a couple of inches towards the wall. Place one hand on the wall once you reach it, then continue to walk each hand up the wall until your body creates a straight line into the wall and right-angle triangle with the wall and floor for any observer from the side. Walk back down the wall one hand at a time until you reach your starting position to complete one rep.

Stand facing a wall with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a medicine ball in one palm, positioned tight to your shoulder with your elbow bent and in front of you. Shift your weight slightly onto the leg
opposite the throwing arm. Explosively push the ball forward into the wall, fully extending your arm at the release.

Using a 45 Degree Back Extension Machine, setup with your feet locked in place and crease of your hip against the pads. Holding a kettlebell, weight plate or dumbbell against your chest, slightly lean forward, to a position where your body is still in alignment. Hold this position for time prescribed. 

Targeting the glutes and proximal hamstring.
