Sit on the rowing machine with your feet secured in the straps and hands gripping the handle. Push powerfully through your legs, then lean back slightly while pulling the handle to your chest. Reverse the motion in a controlled manner, keeping the stroke smooth and efficient. Use maximum effort during work intervals and recover fully during rests.

Run in place while driving your knees high, but instead of moving forward, move backwards. Use quick, light steps and swing your arms
naturally.

Start on top of a box. Stand with one foot on the edge of a box facing laterally with the other foot hanging off the side. Step off the box to land on the same foot and immediately hop laterally as far as possible. Land in a squatted position still facing to the side.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand, keeping them close to your body. Pull the weights up towards your chin, leading with your elbows. Lower under control and repeat.

Stand two steps back from a low step or platform cc 4". Bound from one foot onto the other toward the step with the third step landing on the step itself. Push off explosively to launch yourself into a sprint upon landing the next step after. Sprint for 10m before decelerating.	4x10m	3	4"

From a neutral position, with each feet under its corresponding shoulder and on the balls of your feet, drop one knee towards the ground shifting your weight to that side. Immediately, push off laterally in the direction of the dropped knee while continuing to face forwards. Cover as much distance laterally as possible and land in a nice neutral stance again.

Exercise Name: Prone Deadbugs with Sliders Feet Only
Exercise Description: Start in a prone position with sliders under your feet. Extend one leg while keeping the opposite knee bent, engaging your core. Return under control, then switch sides.

Sit on a bench with your elbow resting against your inner thigh, holding a dumbbell in one hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, squeezing your biceps at the top, then lower under control. Keep your upper arm stationary throughout.

Stand in front of a box or step, placing your lead foot onto the platform. Drive through your foot, stepping up and bringing your opposite knee to hip height. Lower under control before switching sides.

Stand in a shoulder-width squat position, placing a soft ball, pad or foam roller between your thighs. Lower into a deep squat, keeping your knees tracking forward while squeezing the object throughout. Hold the position before returning to standing.

Stand 5m apart, facing your teammate in an athletic stance. Either player can turn and sprint toward the line 10m behind them at any point. The moment the initiating player’s foot leaves the floor to begin their sprint, the other player may react and chase after them. The chaser wins if they tag the sprinter before they reach the line. Focus on explosive reactions, quick acceleration and maintaining proper sprint mechanics.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart and your knees slightly bent. Push your hips back while keeping your back straight and chest up, lowering your torso until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Return to standing by driving your hips forward.

Stand side by side with a partner, both balancing on one leg. Take turns attempting to stiff-arm each other, using feints and fakes while trying to knock your partner off balance. The goal is to retain your own balance while reacting to your partner’s movements, adjusting your core engagement and foot placement accordingly.

Start in a tall position, standing with your feet hip-width apart and core engaged. Quickly drop into a short stance, bending your knees and lowering your centre of gravity while keeping your chest up. Return to the tall position explosively, resetting before the next rep. Variations include adding resistance bands, performing the drill laterally or incorporating reactive cues to mimic game-speed transitions.

Hold dumbbells at your sides, taking small, controlled steps forward, hinging at the hips as you lower the dumbbells towards the ground while keeping a slight bend in the knees. Maintain tension in the hamstrings and glutes, ensuring each step is deliberate.
Jump laterally from one foot to the other, landing softly and pausing briefly before bounding back. Keep your chest up and use your arms for balance.
Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing vertically in place with quick, reactive movements. Keep knees slightly bent and ensure minimal ground contact time.

With one knee up at waist height, plant the other foot into the ground. Raise one arm and put the other down to your side in typical sprinting motion (the opposite of your leg positions). While moving forwards, switch which knee and opposite arm are raised in typical sprinting motion, spending as little time as possible on the ground in between before returning to starting position.

Step one foot across the front of the other so that it drops just in front and to the other side. As this step lands, drop the knee slightly towards the ground, while the standing foot can step to extend out to the side. This will shift your weight back in the opposite direction. From there turn your back hip over while opening the front hip into a 5m acceleration. Apply maximal effort across these initial steps.

Attach a parachute to a sprint harness around your waist and stand in a ready sprint position. Begin sprinting explosively forward, maintaining a low drive phase until resistance builds from the parachute. Keep your stride powerful and controlled, with an aggressive arm drive and knee lift. Continue sprinting until the parachute fully inflates then decelerate gradually.
Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Swing your arms across your body and out to the sides in a dynamic motion. This helps loosen up the chest and shoulders.

Stand facing a wall with your hands resting against it for support. Lean forward slightly, so your body is at an angle and lift one knee to hip height with the foot flexed. Hold this position, ensuring your shin angle is forward and aligned with your sprint mechanics. Maintain tension in your core and legs, holding for the specified duration before switching legs.

Start on your toes with arms raised above head to stretch as tall as possible. Throw your heels down to the ground violently at the same time as your arms and entire weight. You should finish in a
controlled squat position. From there, immediately leap as far in front of yourself as possible. Upon
landing in the same squatted position, maintain momentum while immediately jumping as high as
possible into the air. Have your partner throw the ball in at a challenging height where you can only
reach it at full stretch. The aim is to grab the ball in the air and then control your landing.
Stand with feet together, then jump explosively into an "X" shape, spreading your arms and legs outward mid-air before landing softly in the starting position. Maintain control and rhythm.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Engage your core and ensure your posture is upright. Start by hopping forward on one foot, always keeping the other foot off the ground. As you hop, swing one arm forward and one arm back to maintain balance and mimic running mechanics. After completing the hops on one side, switch to your other foot and repeat the same process. Keep in mind, that arms must swing opposite to the hop, mimicking the natural arm swing during running. Aim for a rhythmical, springy hop rather than a high or long jump. Your landing foot should spring off the ground as soon as it touches down, emphasising the reactive strength component. After completing the first set on both sides moving forward, do the same moving left and then moving right. Each time, you should keep minimal ground contact time as the focus, rather than height or distance.

Standing with your feet slightly outside of line with your shoulders in a very slight squat position. Hold the end of a barbell in both hands towards one side of your body. Lift upwards and over an imaginary fence in front of you to switch the barbell to the other side of your body. Twist your torso and hips with each repetition.

Start in a half-kneeling position with your front knee at 90 degrees and your back knee resting on the floor. Hold a weight plate overhead with both hands, keeping your arms fully extended. Rotate your torso towards the side of your front leg, keeping your hips stable and core engaged. Slowly return to the centre and repeat on the other side.

Exercise Name: Unilateral Bosch Hold with Plate Press Supine
Exercise Description: Lie on your back, holding a weight plate in one hand while keeping your opposite leg elevated. Press the plate overhead, maintaining core and hip stability. Hold the position before switching sides.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip a barbell with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Hinge at the hips and bend your knees slightly, keeping your back straight. Pull the barbell explosively toward your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top. Lower the bar back to the starting position with control.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand, keeping them close to your body. Pull the weights up towards your chin, leading with your elbows. Lower under control and repeat.

Start in a split stance position with one foot forward and the other foot back, hips square and knees slightly bent. Keep your weight balanced evenly between both feet and maintain a tall, upright posture. From this position, extend your arms straight out in front of you. Slowly reach your hands forward as far as possible while maintaining your base and alignment – you should feel your front glute and hamstring engage to stabilise, while your core works to resist any rotation or collapse forward. Return to the upright position with control and repeat. Repeat on both sides.

Place cones in a T-shape with one cone at the base and three cones in a straight line at the top. Start at the base cone, sprint forward to the middle cone (10m), then shuffle laterally to one side cone (5m). Shuffle the opposite direction to the far side cone (10m). Shuffle back to the centre (5m). Then backpedal to the start (10m). Maintain a low stance
throughout the drill.

Start with your toes over the edge of the box and your arms raised above your head to stretch as tall as possible. Step
off the box and allow gravity to take you down towards the ground. Land on both feet and immediately jump vertically as quickly as possible. You should then land in a controlled split squat position to dissipate your force into the ground.

Begin in a standard push-up position with your hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Engage your
core and keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. Lower your chest towards the ground by bending your elbows. When you reach the bottom of the press-up, explosively push off the ground with enough force for your hands to leave the floor. If possible, clap your hands together before landing softly back in the starting position. Immediately go into the next push-up, maintaining a rapid and controlled tempo.

Begin in a tall posture with your core engaged, standing with your feet hip-width apart. Drive one knee up towards waist height, keeping your toe dorsiflexed (pointed up), while simultaneously pushing off the opposite foot into a skip. Land softly on the ball of your foot, immediately repeating the movement on the other side in a rhythmic and powerful motion. Keep your arms active, driving them in coordination with your legs while maintaining an upright sprint posture and quick ground contacts.

Anchor a resistance band at eye level. Hold the band with both hands, palms facing down. Pull the band towards your face, focusing on retracting your shoulder blades. This activates the upper back and rear delts, preparing for pulling movements like rows.

Sit facing a cable machine with a wide grip on the bar. Pull the bar down towards your chest, keeping your elbows pointed down and back. Lower under control, then return to the start position. Maintain a tight core and stable posture throughout.
Perform Split Stance Pogos, but moving forward, keeping quick, controlled movements and maintaining reactive strength.

Exercise Name: Diagonal Drop Step into Vertical Jump
Exercise Description: Step diagonally out in front and to one side and bend at the knee to drop lower to the ground. Sink your weight through this plant foot to load up, then immediately push through the ground to jump vertically as high as possible.
Perform quick, reactive jumps, alternating between left, left, right or other set patterns. Maintain rhythm and minimal ground contact time while keeping an upright posture.

Set a barbell at a low position on safety pins inside a squat rack, placing it at the bottom of your squat depth. Stand underneath the bar with a front rack grip, ensuring your elbows remain high and core engaged. From a dead stop, drive through your heels and midfoot, standing up with full control before lowering back down to the pins. Reset between reps to eliminate momentum and reinforce pure strength development.

Exercise Name: Nordic Eccentric Full Range of Motion
Exercise Description: Begin in a tall kneeling position with feet secured. Lower yourself slowly towards the floor, maintaining a neutral spine. Go as low as possible, then return to the start. The goal is full range of motion with eccentric control.
Sit on an incline bench, holding dumbbells at shoulder height. Press the weights overhead, fully extending your arms without locking out. Lower under control and repeat.
Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing forwards and backwards while maintaining quick, reactive foot contacts. Focus on explosiveness and minimal ground contact time.

Stand inside a trap bar with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the handles firmly. Rise up onto your toes, then quickly drop into a quarter squat by releasing tension and catching the bar with a strong, stable posture. Absorb the weight by bracing through the core and legs, and ensure the catch is quiet and controlled. Reset between reps to maintain quality and avoid bouncing.

Stand side-on to a wall, holding a medicine ball at chest height with both hands. Shift your weight onto your back leg, then rotate through your hips and core, driving the ball explosively into the wall using only your lead arm. Catch the rebound or reset before repeating. Focus on full-body coordination, ensuring the power comes from your legs and torso rather than just the arm.

Walk forward while driving one knee up towards your chest, then alternate legs. With each step, bring your knee as high as possible while maintaining an upright posture. This movement activates the hip flexors and warms up the lower body for sprinting and bounding.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Step sideways into a deep lateral lunge, bending your outside knee while keeping your inside leg straight. As you lower, reach both hands toward your foot to deepen the stretch and reinforce balance. Push through your bent leg to return to standing, keeping your core engaged and chest upright throughout.

Start in a tall kneeling position on a smooth floor with sliders under your knees. Slowly slide your knees apart, maintaining control and upright posture as the inner thighs lengthen. Pause when you reach your limit, then use the adductors to pull your knees back in. Keep your hips square and avoid leaning forward or backward. Focus on smooth, symmetrical movement and inner thigh engagement.

Stand on a low step or box with one foot on the platform and the other leg hovering off the edge. Slowly lower yourself by bending the standing leg, controlling the descent until the opposite heel lightly taps the floor. Push through your heel and midfoot to return to standing, simultaneously driving the opposite knee toward your chest into a hip-flexion hold. Maintain core engagement and knee alignment throughout.

Exercise Name: Lunge Drops with Medicine Ball Held Out
Exercise Description: Start in a split squat position holding a dumbbell with both hands extended straight out in front of you at shoulder height. Keeping your arms locked and core engaged lift your front foot slightly off the ground shifting your weight onto the back leg. Allow gravity to drop you into a deeper split squat as your front foot returns to the floor. Control the landing by absorbing the impact through your front leg while keeping your torso upright and the dumbbell extended.

Stand tall with feet hip-width apart, hands resting on a wall or support for balance if needed. Press through the balls of your feet to rise slowly onto your toes, fully contracting the calves. Pause briefly at the top, then lower under full control to a deep stretch in the heels. Maintain a deliberate, slow tempo throughout, focusing on maximum tension and controlled range of motion.

Lie flat on your back with your arms extended to the sides. Lift your legs to 90 degrees, then rotate them slowly towards one side, keeping your shoulders flat on the floor. Return to the centre and repeat on the other side.

Start in an athletic stance and bound diagonally off one foot to land on the opposite leg. Immediately after landing, hinge at the hips while keeping the back flat, reaching both arms towards the floor. Return to standing and reset. The bound should be powerful and controlled, while the hinge following it should reinforce balance, hip stability and posterior chain engagement. Avoid collapsing or twisting through the torso.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and hands placed on your hips or at your sides for balance. Shift your weight slightly onto one leg while lifting the opposite knee to about hip height. From this position, draw a large, controlled circular motion with your lifted knee, moving outward and then downward before bringing it back to the starting position. Reverse the movement after completing all reps in one direction. Keep your core engaged, and ensure your hips remain square to the front without excessive torso movement.

Stand in a split stance with your front heel elevated on a plate or small wedge. Hold dumbbells by your sides and lower your back knee toward the ground while keeping your torso upright. Push through your front heel to return to standing.
Stand on one leg, bouncing lightly on the inside edge of your foot, keeping quick, reactive contacts. Maintain balance and control throughout. Switch legs after completing reps.

Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Press both arms straight up so the dumbbells are directly above your shoulders and remain extended. Lower one dumbbell slowly to chest level while keeping the other fully extended. Press it back up to match the other. Alternate sides each rep. Maintain tension through the extended arm and keep your feet planted firmly throughout.

Sprint 40 metres
all out from a standstill and measure the time it takes to reach each of these splits. Use speed gates for accuracy, or otherwise film with a cone to mark
each distance and take the times afterwards. Retain
only the splits from the fastest 40 metre sprint (note that this is metres not yards).
Stand on one leg on a wobble board, keeping your knee slightly bent. Maintain balance and stability while resisting unnecessary movement. Switch sides after completing the reps.

Stand perpendicular to the Keiser machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grip the handle with both hands at hip height. Take a step away from the machine to create tension on the cable. Begin by rotating your torso and hips towards the machine, pivoting on your outside foot for an extra twist. Quickly rotate away from the machine to face the other way. Switch your grip mid-swing and punch the handle forward as you complete the rotation, fully extending your arms. Return to the starting position with control, maintaining tension on the cable throughout. Think of the rotation similar to the motion behind a golf or baseball bat swing.
Sit on a hip adduction machine, positioning your legs outside the pads. Bring your knees together, squeezing at the end range, then return under control. Maintain a stable core throughout.

1. Set up a triangle or multiple boxes with a smaller triangle at the base as below in the images.

The end box should be 5x5x5. The larger box should be 10 metres long on top of the end box and the end line should have two end points diagonal from the end box (think of centre-field
in baseball).

2. One player starts on the goalline and one inside the end box. The player on the goalline
should whip the ball into the end box at speed or in the air to make it difficult to control.

3. Within 2 touches the player in the end zone should exit the end box through either of two
smaller 1m exit zones. Once outside they can be tacked.

4. The other player is able to press at speed as soon as they play the ball and should have
gotten tight into a 1v1.

5. The player on the ball must reach the long goal line and stop the ball dead on it to score (and keep on as the attacker). The game is over if the ball leaves the box any other way and players should subsequently switch roles.

6. Free-kicks are given if a player is fouled (the defender may not press until the attacker takes
their first touch).

Penalties are given if a player is fouled when ahead of the defender and through on goal (the defender may not press until the attacker has left the end box).

Step off a box or platform and drop naturally, landing with soft knees and immediately exploding into a vertical jump. Focus on quick ground contact to jump with speed, then ensuring the landing after is smooth and controlled.

Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight in front of you. Keep your torso tall and hands resting at your sides. Lift one leg a few inches off the ground, keeping the knee straight and avoiding leaning back. Lower with control and switch sides. If needed, place your hands slightly behind you for balance.

Start in a shoulder-width squat stance. Lower as normal until your upper legs sit 90 degrees parallel to the floor. Push upwards one inch, drop one inch and then push up through the entire squat motion back to upright in one fast simultaneous set of movements. Use the small countermovement to overcome the inertia and perform the upward portion of the squat at maximum speed.
Stand tall with your core engaged, bouncing backward on the balls of your feet with quick, reactive contacts. Keep your knees slightly bent and ensure minimal ground contact time.

Stand behind the sled with your hands gripping the handles, positioning your torso at a forward angle. Drive through the balls of your feet, pushing the sled forward in a continuous, sprint-like motion, ensuring each stride is forceful and explosive. Keep your core engaged and hips low, focusing on smooth, powerful leg drive. Avoid short, choppy steps - each push should be fluid and efficient, maintaining momentum without breaking stride.
Perform a seated row using one arm at a time, keeping the torso upright. Pull the handle towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blade, then return under control. Repeat before switching sides.
Walk forward on your toes with your heels off the ground. Keep your core engaged and shoulders relaxed as you take small, controlled steps.

Start in a quadruped (all-fours) position with your hands directly under your shoulders and knees under your hips. While keeping a neutral spine, slowly push your hips back toward your heels, allowing your arms to extend forward while maintaining contact with the ground. As you reach the bottom position, lift one arm and rotate your torso, reaching your hand toward the ceiling while keeping the other hand planted. Pause briefly before returning to the start position and alternating sides. Maintain control throughout, avoiding excessive spinal movement.

Stand facing a wall with your hands pressed against it at shoulder height, leaning forward at an approximate 45-degree angle. Start with one knee lifted toward your chest and the other leg extended behind. Drive the rear leg forward while simultaneously bringing the opposite knee down, switching legs in one explosive motion while maintaining a rigid core and stable upper body. Quickly reset to the starting position and repeat the switch as fast as possible while maintaining proper mechanics. Focus on forceful knee drive, active foot placement under the hips and minimising ground contact time.

Stand in a staggered fighting stance (one foot in front of the other and shoulder-width apart) with the front foot horizontal to the end of a landmine barbell. Drop backwards into a squat, then as you push upwards, rotate towards the landmine while pressing the barbell in the same direction at the same time. Ensure that you keep your shoulder and therefore body behind the load.
Stand on the balls of your feet, bouncing quickly in a criss-cross pattern, alternating your feet over and under each other with rapid foot contacts. Maintain minimal ground contact time.

Accelerate up to a high speed and then use random triggers, either called out by a teammate or from flashing lights on your phone, to change direction 45 degrees and continue moving. Slow down to a stop before resetting to repeat.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart in an athletic stance. Begin leaning forward from your ankles, keeping your body straight and your core engaged. When you feel yourself about to lose balance, push off explosively into a sprint by driving your lead leg forward and swinging your arms naturally. Focus on a strong first step and maintaining a low forward body angle as you accelerate.

Hold a weight plate overhead with both hands, keeping your arms fully extended and core tight. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then lift one knee towards hip height while smoothly swiping it over an imaginary hurdle in an outward arc. Keep your posture tall and your movement controlled, ensuring your hips remain stable and do not excessively shift. Lower the leg back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Start in an athletic stance, with your feet hip-width apart and knees slightly bent. Push off your outside foot, crossing one leg over the other into a lateral step, landing softly and under control. Upon landing, immediately balance on the outside foot, holding for a brief pause before resetting. Keep your core engaged and focus on stability, avoiding excessive swaying.

Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then bend at the hips to reach for your toes, keeping your legs straight to stretch your hamstrings. From this position, bend your knees and drop into a deep squat, ensuring your heels stay on the ground. Hold briefly, then extend your legs back to the forward fold position before repeating.

Set up a cable machine at ankle height or attach a resistance band to a low anchor point. Assume a half-kneeling position with your front foot flat and your back knee on the ground, ensuring your hips are stacked over your back knee. Attach the cable or band to your front ankle and move forward slightly to create tension. From this position, drive your front knee toward your chest while keeping your torso upright and core engaged. Hold the knee at its highest position for two seconds, focusing on activating the hip flexors and maintaining balance. Slowly return to the starting position without losing control.

Stand approximately 5-10 metres away from your partner in an athletic stance, with your feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent, and weight distributed on the balls of your feet. Keep your eyes focused on the partner holding the ball at waist height, ready to react. Your partner will randomly throw the ball towards the ground in any direction. As soon as you see the ball leave their hands, explode into a sprint, driving off your back foot and keeping your strides quick and powerful. Aim to reach the ball and catch it before it bounces for a second time - with neutral body weight at the time of the catch. Focus on maintaining proper sprint mechanics, with your arms driving naturally and your chest leaning slightly forward before stabilising into a neutral position at the time of the catch. Adjust the starting distance to push your speed to the edge of your ability.

Lie flat on your back, keeping your legs straight. Engage your core and hip flexors, then lift your legs towards 90 degrees, keeping them straight. Lower slowly under control, avoiding excessive arching of the lower back.

Start by moving at speed then slam the brakes on to decelerate as fast as possible. While retaining some of the force from the sprint, push off laterally with the aim of covering as much distance to the side as possible. Think pressing and gambling to one side.
Stand on one leg, maintaining postural control. Keep your core engaged and avoid excessive swaying. Hold the position for the prescribed time before switching sides.

Laying on the ground, place your feet onto a box or bench. From this position, push your feet into the box/bench, and raise your hips into a glute bridge. Ensure you maintain a neutral pelvis/spine through gentle squeeze of your core. Hold this position for prescribed time.

Start in a deep squat position with your hips below your knees and your chest upright. Begin walking forward by taking small steps, staying low and maintaining your squat. Keep your heels grounded and avoid rounding your lower back. For an added challenge, hold a light weight at your chest or extend your arms forward.

Stand tall with a slight forward lean, keeping your core engaged and ankles stiff. Rapidly lift and lower your knees just above shin height, maintaining quick, light foot contacts directly under your hips. Keep the movement fast and controlled, avoiding excessive vertical displacement.

Attach a cable handle to a machine at chest height. Stand sideways to the machine with a shoulder-width stance, gripping the handle with both hands at your sternum. Brace your core and glutes, then press the handle straight forward, resisting rotational pull. Once fully extended, continue the movement upward until it is overhead, without arching your lower back. Hold for a second before slowly lowering the handle back along the same path, controlling every phase of the movement.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your arms by your sides. Lower yourself into a squat position with your thighs parallel to the ground. Explode upward into a vertical jump, extending your legs fully and swinging your arms for momentum. Land softly on the balls of your feet, returning to the squat position. Hold this position for 2 seconds before repeating the movement. Focus on maintaining control during the hold and generating maximum power during the jump.
Dynamic Hip Flexor Stretch
Repetitions: Start in a half-kneeling position with your front knee at a 90-degree angle and your back knee resting on the ground. Keep your torso upright and core engaged as you gently push your hips forward, feeling a stretch in the hip flexor of the back leg. Avoid arching your lower back by maintaining a neutral spine

Exercise Description: Stand in a staggered fighting stance (one foot in front of the other and shoulder-width apart) with the front foot horizontal to the end of a landmine barbell. Lean your body forward and grip the barbell while it rests on the floor. Rest your other arm on your front leg. Without moving your back, pull the end of the barbell up until your elbow is level with your body. Slowly lower it back down until your elbow is almost straight to reset and repeat.

Exercise Name: Standing Knee Hug to Quad Pull
Exercise Description: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart. Lift one knee towards your chest and hug it tightly with both arms, keeping your standing leg straight. Hold briefly, then release and grab the ankle of the same leg behind you, pulling the heel towards your glutes in a quad stretch. Hold again, then step forward and repeat on the other leg. Maintain balance and an upright posture throughout the movement.

Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight in front of you, holding the end of a barbell in a landmine attachment with both hands. Keep your torso upright and core engaged as you press the bar overhead in a straight line. Fully extend your arms at the top of the movement, then lower the bar back down to shoulder height with control. Maintain an upright posture throughout the exercise, avoiding any leaning or rounding of the back.
Sprint up a flight of stairs, driving your knees high and maintaining quick foot contacts. Focus on powerful strides and explosiveness. Walk down and repeat.

Stand behind a sled with your hands gripping the handles, positioning your torso at a forward angle. Drive through the balls of your feet, keeping your core tight and steps powerful as you push the sled forward. Maintain consistent tension, ensuring hips remain low and your knees stay aligned throughout the movement. Keep your strides short and forceful, accelerating with controlled momentum rather than relying on sheer upper-body force.

Exercise Name: 3 Step to Deceleration Drop to Back Pedal
Exercise Description: Perform three aggressive sprint steps, then transition into an immediate controlled deceleration by lowering your hips and absorbing force through your legs. As you come to a stop, push off aggressively into a backpedal, maintaining a low, balanced position with active arm movement. Keep your weight slightly forward to allow for quick directional changes.

Place the weight between your knee and groin area and squeeze each leg into the weight tightly. Hold onto two bars either side to lift yourself off the ground from a standing position. Lower yourself until your elbows are bent between 45 and 90 degrees. Control the movement throughout the range of motion. Push yourself back up slowly until your arms are almost straight and repeat.

Stand in front of a box or step, holding dumbbells in each hand. Step up with one foot, pausing briefly at the top position, then lower under control. Keep your core engaged and torso upright throughout.

Wrap a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Stand tall and begin driving one knee up towards hip height while the other leg pushes off the ground. Alternate legs quickly while swinging your arms naturally, maintaining tension in the band throughout.

Take three powerful sprint steps forward, then suddenly decelerate, lowering your centre of gravity while absorbing force through your quads, glutes and hamstrings. Keep your chest up and arms active, ensuring a smooth and controlled stop without excessive forward lean.

Exercise Name: Bilateral Deceleration + 90 degree turn into sprint
Exercise Description: Start on your tip toes with your arms above your head as tall as possible. Throw all your weight down into the ground as quickly as possible, then immediately leap forwards as far as possible, landing and controlling the following leap.

Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet hovering slightly above the ground. Hold a weight or clasp your hands together. Twist your torso to one side, bringing your hands toward the floor beside your hip, then rotate to the opposite side in a controlled manner while keeping your core engaged.
Sprint all out until you can no longer sustain maximum speed. Measure the number of seconds until this point is reached.
Stand tall with a dumbbell in each hand, keeping your elbows close to your body. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top before lowering under control.

Exercise Name:
Drop Jump + Split Squat +
Forward Shuffle
Exercise Description: Start with both of your heels on the edge of a box and then step off, allowing gravity to take you towards the ground. Immediately jump vertically as high as possible. Land this jump in a split squat with one leg out in front of you and the other’s knee facing down towards the ground. Having controlled the momentum in this split squat, sprint forwards a few steps. Keep the same maximal level of intent for this exercise and accelerate as fast as possible through those steps.

Accelerate across 5 metres to pick up some momentum, then coordinate your feet with three steps to decelerate and then immediately turn 90° either to the left or right to burst out 5m in that direction. Apply maximal effort across these initial steps.

Start in an athletic stance with your feet shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent, and weight shifted onto the balls of your feet. Lean forward slightly, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. Drive off your back foot explosively, focusing on short, powerful strides during the first few steps. Swing your arms aggressively to generate momentum, keeping your elbows bent at 90 degrees. Maintain a low body position as you accelerate through the 10m distance. Come to a full stop before resetting for the next repetition.

Start in a side plank position, with your shoulder facing towards the ground. The
corresponding arm should be outstretched with the palm of your hand and the side of one foot connecting to the ground. With your free arm, touch the elbow of the arm on the side of the injured shoulder while retaining your balance. Return this arm into the air above you before repeating the
same process.

Set up a Smith machine with a bench underneath. Assume regular bench press position with your shoulders pinned
back and chest poked out. Grip the bar just wider than shoulder-width apart. Lower the bar to your chest, then
explosively press it upward letting go at the top of the motion. Focus on the speed of the movement while maintaining control. Catch the bar softly by dropping your hands at a slower motion than the bar instead of at a single point. This will help to reduce the impact. Ensure you have safety catches on the smith machine just above head height just in case you fail to catch the bar correctly.

Using a squat rack or smith machine, place the barriers at knee height. Assume the starting deadlift position, hinging
from the hips with hands placed on the barbell just outside shoulder-width apart. As you pull upwards, the barrier will
prevent the bar from moving. Continue to pull with force for the desired duration, before dropping the bar and
releasing the tension.

Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at hip height with an overhand grip. Your hands should be
shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and slightly bend your knees and hips, allowing the barbell to lower to just
above your knees. From this position, explosively extend your hips, knees, and ankles, pulling the barbell upward
towards your chest. Keep the bar close to your body and your elbows high, aiming to bring the bar up to chest level.
Lower the barbell back to hip height and repeat. Focus on maintaining a powerful and controlled motion throughout
the exercise.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand, extending your arms straight overhead with your palms facing forward. Keeping your arms straight, slowly lower the dumbbells behind your head, maintaining control before returning to the start position. Avoid excessive arching of the lower back.
Step one foot across your body while simultaneously swinging your arms overhead. Alternate sides, moving laterally. Keep your core engaged and movements smooth.

Kneel on the ground. Drop back towards your heels and then quickly create forward momentum to jump upwards. Land on one foot and immediately hop laterally as far as possible. If you land on your right foot, this hop should be made to your left side, with landing on your left foot meaning a hop to the right.

Stand tall next to a stable surface, such as a fence or pole, for balance. Shift your weight onto one leg and swing the opposite leg forward and backward in a controlled motion. Keep your torso upright, your core engaged, and avoid arching your back. Start with a small range of motion and gradually increase the height of the swing as your hip flexors and hamstrings loosen. Repeat all reps on one leg before switching to the other.

Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, hinge at the hips, and keep your back flat. Row the dumbbell towards your ribcage, squeezing your shoulder blade, then lower under control. Repeat before switching sides.

From a standing position, reach forward with your hands while taking one foot and stepping backwards behind your body at a 45 degree angle. This is the same position as a “curtsy”. Then, push off from your front foot as far laterally as possible to land on what was your back foot in the curtsy again. You should be able to repeat this from side-to-side while retaining your balance.
Sit with a foam roller under your calf. Slowly roll up and down the length of your calf, pausing on any tight spots.
Stand on one leg with a slight knee bend. Hinge at the hips, rotating your torso toward the planted leg, then rotate outward, opening the hips. Keep control and balance.
Perform quick, low bounces on the balls of your feet, keeping the legs relatively straight and focusing on stiffness in the ankles.

Hang from gymnastic rings with a supinated grip (palms facing you). Pull yourself up until your chin clears the rings, squeezing your lats and biceps, then lower under control. Avoid excessive swinging.

Stand tall with a slight forward lean, keeping your core engaged and knees soft. Rapidly lift and lower each foot in quick succession, mimicking an accelerative sprint motion while ensuring short, reactive ground contacts. Focus on ankle stiffness and maintaining a rhythmic stride pattern, keeping the movement fluid and controlled.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height with elbows bent and palms facing in. Step one foot back into a lunge position, keeping your front knee over the ankle. At the bottom of the lunge, press both dumbbells overhead in a controlled motion. Lower the weights back to shoulder height as you return to standing. Keep your core engaged and avoid arching your lower back during the press.

Exercise Name: Lunge Drops with Medicine Ball at Chest
Exercise Description: Start in a split squat position holding a medicine ball against your chest. Lift your front foot momentarily, then allow gravity to pull you down into a deeper lunge as you absorb the landing. Keep the medicine ball tight to your chest, ensuring your torso remains upright and stable. Control the descent and drive back up with force before repeating.

Hold a dumbbell or kettlebell at chest height, standing with your feet hip-width apart. Step laterally into a deep lunge, bending your outside knee while keeping your inside leg straight. Keep your torso upright and core engaged, then push through the outside foot to return to standing. Maintain control and avoid collapsing at the hip or knee.

Start on your tiptoes with your arms raised above your head, reaching as tall as possible. Engage your core and, in one
swift motion, throw all your weight down into the ground, bending your knees and hips to land in a controlled squat position. Your feet should be shoulder-width apart, and your knees should be tracking over your toes. Hold the squat
position briefly to ensure control, then return to the starting position and repeat.

Stand sideways to a cable machine, gripping the handle at hip height. Rotate your torso upwards, pulling the handle diagonally across your body towards your opposite shoulder. Control the return and repeat. Keep your feet planted.

Lie on your side with your legs stacked and your bottom arm supporting your head. Keep your top leg straight and lift it upward toward the ceiling, ensuring your movement comes from the hip rather than the lower back. Lower it back down under control without letting it rest fully before repeating. Focus on keeping your hips square and preventing rotation.

On one leg, drop into a squat position with your opposite leg extending out in front of you. For
assistance you can either tie a band between two posts and drop with the band under you, or if not
possible, by holding a dumbbell out in front you.

Stand facing the sled, gripping the handles firmly with both hands. Keep your torso upright, core engaged and shoulders pulled back to maintain a strong posture. Begin stepping backward one foot at a time, keeping your steps short and controlled while maintaining constant tension on the sled. Focus on driving through your heels, ensuring your knees track forward and your back remains straight. Avoid leaning excessively or jerking the sled—each step should be deliberate and forceful, reinforcing eccentric control and posterior chain activation. Maintain a consistent rhythm, keeping the sled moving smoothly throughout the movement.

Attach a resistance band around your waist, anchoring it to the side. Begin in an athletic stance, then step laterally against the band's resistance, maintaining control. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Stand facing the cable machine, with a handle attachment low to the ground. Hold this one hand while standing completely upright. Your aim is to maintain a straight arm while raising it out to one
side and up to shoulder-height in a circular motion. The tension will increase throughout this
motion. If you are unable to complete the full movement without pain, raise to the point at which you are comfortable for each rep. If unable to complete the movement altogether, replace the cable with a light resistance band.

Attach a resistance band around your ankle, securing the other end to a low anchor. Stand sideways to the anchor and bring your inside leg across your body, maintaining control before returning to the start. Keep tension throughout.

Attach a cable with a rope attachment at a low setting, stepping forward with the cable running between your legs. Hinge at your hips, allowing your torso to lean forward while maintaining a neutral spine. Drive through your glutes and hamstrings to return to standing, squeezing at the top.

Exercise Name: Drop Jump to Leap to Backpedal
Exercise Description: Begin on a low box. Step off into a controlled drop jump, land and instantly explode into a forward leap. Upon landing, absorb the force and transition straight into a quick, reactive backpedal. Stay low and balanced throughout.

Exercise Name: Standing Long Jump to Sprint Position
Exercise Description: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and arms extended behind you. Perform a maximal horizontal jump by swinging your arms forward and explosively pushing off both feet. Land softly with knees bent and immediately drop into a low split stance sprint position - one foot forward and one back, chest over the lead knee and arms loaded in a sprint-ready posture. Hold this final position for a second to establish control and alignment before resetting.

Hang from a pullup bar with a wide grip – starting with your hands just outside of your shoulders and facing away from your body. Pull yourself upwards so that your chin reaches level with the bar, then slowly lower yourself down again. Keep your feet off the ground at all times during sets.

Kneel sideways to a cable machine, gripping the handle with both hands at hip height. Rotate your torso upwards, pulling the handle diagonally across your body towards your opposite shoulder. Control the return and repeat.

Start in a standard push-up position with your hands under your shoulders. Lower your chest to the ground, then push explosively off the ground so that your hands leave the floor. Land softly and go straight into the next repetition.

Place one end of a barbell in a landmine attachment or securely in a corner, with the other end held at shoulder height
in one hand. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and engage your core. Start in a slight squat position, then
press the barbell forward and upward until your arm is fully extended. Your body should rotate slightly to allow for a
natural pressing motion. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions before switching to the other arm.
Sit on a bench with both feet flat on the floor. Without resistance, lift your toes toward your shins, keeping your heels planted. Slowly lower back down.
Secure a resistance band around your ankle, anchoring it behind you. Step forward to create tension and perform slow ankle dorsiflexion movements, allowing the band to assist joint mobility.

Stand in front of your partner in a typical 1v1 defensive stance - low centre of gravity and one foot slightly in front of the other. Begin to shift your feet backwards while alternating your angle with each step as if to show your partner in a desired direction. Your partner should step forward to
follow you. Anytime they call “touch”, you must dart forward with an outstretched arm to touch them, before returning to the backward shuffle as before. They should do this several times before silently turning and sprinting the opposite direction from you. When this happens, you must react quickly to switch into forward momentum and chase them, getting a touch within 20m to win.

Sit on the ground facing a wall with your legs bent at 90 degrees and feet flat on the wall. Place a foam roller or small ball between each leg and squeeze tightly on it with each leg. Lift your lower back slightly off the ground. From this start position, drop one hip towards the ground as far as possible. Hold momentarily, then raise this hip while dropping the opposite side. Repeat until completion.

Start standing tall with your feet shoulder-width apart and your arms by your sides. Swing your arms back as you hinge at the hips, then drive them forward as you explode into a broad jump. Land softly on the balls of your feet with your knees bent and hips back, absorbing the impact. Hold the landing position for 2–3 seconds, ensuring balance and stability before resetting for the next jump.

Lie face down on the ground with your hands under your shoulders and legs fully extended. At the command, explosively push off the ground, drive one knee forward and transition into a full sprint as quickly as possible. Keep your first steps powerful and low, maintaining a forward lean and quick ground contacts.

Hang from a pull-up bar with a supinated grip (palms facing you), keeping your legs extended straight in an L-shape. Pull yourself up until your chin clears the bar, maintaining core engagement, then lower under control.

Attach a cable at waist height and stand side-on to the machine. Hold the handle with both hands and step out into a wide lateral stance. Drive the hips laterally away from the machine, resisting the pull of the cable as you shift weight side-to-side. Return to centre with control. Keep the core tight and move with purpose - the emphasis is on resisting rotation and strengthening frontal plane stability.

Lie face down with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Engage your core and glutes, then lift your arms and legs slightly off the ground. Begin a controlled, alternating movement, raising one arm and the opposite leg higher while lowering the other side. Keep the motion smooth and controlled, avoiding excessive back arching.

Place a weight plate or dumbbell between your thighs. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. Start by engaging your shoulder blades, pulling them down and back. Drive your chest upwards explosively until your chin clears the bar, keeping your body straight without excessive swinging. Lower yourself under control to the starting position and reset before the next repetition.

Perform a single-leg balance, but with your non-support leg raised to hip height (A-position). Maintain core stability and avoid excessive movement. Hold for the prescribed time before switching sides.

Attach an ankle strap to a low pulley on the cable machine and secure it around one ankle. Stand facing the machine, holding onto the frame or handles for stability. Begin with your working leg slightly bent and your foot forward. Kick this leg straight back in a controlled, powerful motion, extending your hip until your leg is fully extended behind you. Keep your core tight and avoid arching your lower back. Slowly return your leg to the starting position and repeat on the same side before switching legs.
Jump laterally from one foot to the other, landing softly and pausing briefly before bounding back. Keep your chest up and use your arms for balance.

Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended and your legs straight. Engage your core and keep your body
stable. Lift your legs up towards your chest, keeping them as straight as possible. Aim to bring your legs up to a 90-
degree angle with your torso. Hold the top position briefly, then slowly lower your legs back to the starting position with control.

Stand in front of a box or bench with a barbell on your back. Place one foot on the box, making sure your whole foot is
secure. Engage your core and drive through the heel of your front foot to lift your body onto the box. As you step up,
simultaneously drive your opposite knee up towards your chest, mimicking a running motion. Lower your raised leg
back to the ground in a controlled manner and then step down with your other leg. Repeat the movement for the
prescribed number of reps on one leg before switching to the other.

Hold a pair of gymnastic rings or TRX handles and lean back into a horizontal row position. Row your chest up to the rings by driving the elbows back and squeezing the shoulder blades together. At the top, transition smoothly into a press by punching the hands forward and upward until the arms are straight in front of you. Lower back to the start position under control and repeat.
Step back into a controlled reverse lunge. As you return to standing, drive your knee up toward your chest.

Start in a kneeling position on a soft surface, with your torso upright and your knees about hip-width apart. Begin the movement by explosively driving your hips forward and swinging your arms to help propel your body upward into a squat position. Once you land on your feet, immediately perform a jump squat by lowering into a squat and then jumping as high as you can. Land softly and return to the kneeling position to repeat the sequence.

Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and a kettlebell between your feet. Hinge at the hips to grip the kettlebell with both hands. Drive through the heels to stand tall, then immediately pull the kettlebell upward to chest height by bending the elbows and leading with them. Keep the kettlebell close to your body and control the return to the start. Focus on timing the hip extension and high pull as one coordinated movement.
Perform the Overhead Press while seated, using a barbell or dumbbells. Press the weight overhead until fully extended, then lower under control. Maintain core stability throughout.

Lie sideways next to a bench or box and support yourself on your forearm with elbow under shoulder. Place your top leg on the bench with the knee bent at 90 degrees, so the inner thigh rests on the surface. Keep the bottom leg hanging freely beneath. Lift your hips off the floor into a side plank position, forming a straight line from head to knee. Hold the position, keeping hips square and core braced, focusing on adductor engagement.

Accelerate across 5 metres to pick up some momentum, then turn 180° out in the opposite direction aiming to keep the tighest turn possible around the corner. To do so, lean forwards not back, and focus on shifting your hips and then upper body around in a circular motion to use centrifugal force. Think of Earth orbiting the Sun; your hips and then upper body orbiting around your centre-of-mass in a smooth circular motion. Accelerate out 5 metres back to your starting position with full effort.

Start in a kneeling position with one hand behind your head and the other hand on the floor under your shoulder. Rotate your torso to bring your elbow towards your opposite hand, then twist upwards towards the ceiling.

Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place a soft ball, pad or foam roller between your knees. Engage your glutes and core, lifting your hips into a bridge position, while squeezing the object firmly. Hold for the prescribed time.

Start in a side-on stance and move laterally, crossing one leg in front of and then behind the other as you shuffle sideways. Focus on smooth hip and arm movement. Continue until a nice rhythm is found.

Exercise Name: Long Lever Bosch Hold - Bilateral GHD
Exercise Description: Position yourself on a GHD machine, securing both legs under the pads. Keep your torso in a straight-line position, resisting movement. Hold for the prescribed time. A partner may apply light perturbations.

Stand with feet in a wide stance, holding a kettlebell with both hands down in front of you. Shift your weight to one side and lower into a deep lateral squat while keeping the opposite leg straight. Push back through the bent leg to return to the centre, then shift to the other side. Keep your chest up and the kettlebell centred as you move side to side. Maintain tension in both legs throughout.
Hold a dumbbell in one hand, hinge forward slightly, and row the dumbbell towards your ribcage, keeping your elbow tucked. Lower under control and repeat. Switch sides after completing reps.
Perform one-legged lateral bouncing, keeping quick, reactive contacts along the outside edge of your foot. Maintain stability and minimal ground contact time. Switch legs after completing reps.

Sit on a bench or chair with your feet flat on the ground and your knees at a 90-degree angle. Without resistance, lift your toes toward your shins, keeping your heels planted on the floor, then slowly lower back down. Focus on controlled movement, ensuring the tibialis anterior muscles engage properly.

Start in a high plank position with your wrists directly under your shoulders and your feet slightly wider than hip-width for stability. Keeping your core engaged and hips level, lift one hand off the floor and tap the opposite shoulder, then return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side, ensuring minimal torso rotation and maintaining a stable plank position throughout.
Anchor a resistance band at a low point and loop it around your foot just above the toes. Pull your toes toward your shin against the band’s resistance, then return slowly. Perform on both sides.

Set up for a traditional bench press but with a lighter load to prioritise speed. After unracking the barbell, lower it to your chest quickly but under control. Pause momentarily at the bottom, then press the bar upward as fast as possible while maintaining proper form. Focus on an explosive upward phase while ensuring stability through your shoulders and core.

Stand tall with your arms extended straight out to your sides. Begin
making small circles, gradually increasing the size of the circles. After
the full amount of reps forward, switch directions. This movement
activates the shoulders and improves shoulder joint mobility.

Begin seated on a bench or low surface with your feet flat on the ground. Lean forward slightly by hinging at your hips, keeping your back flat and core engaged. Push through your heels to rise into a standing position, focusing on engaging your glutes and hamstrings. Reverse the motion by lowering yourself back to the seated position with control, maintaining the hinge movement at your hips.

Sit on the floor with your knees bent, holding a medicine ball at chest height. Rotate your torso side to side, touching the ball to the ground on each side. Keep your core engaged and avoid excessive swinging.

Hold a dumbbell in each hand to your sides. Step in front with one foot and drop your back knee towards the ground at the same time, Push up from this position through your front foot’s heel back to a standing position. Step forwards with the opposite foot and repeat.

Exercise Name: Hip Opener + 180 Degree Turn into Sprint
Exercise Description: From a neutral position, with each feet under its corresponding shoulder and on the balls of your feet, open one hip to the side such that the corresponding foot faces out in that direction too. Immediately, rotate both hips around in the opposite direction such that the initial opened hip now whips around the corner in the opposite direction to drive the knee into a 10 metre sprint.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides or keeping your hands on your hips. Step forward with one leg into a deep lunge, ensuring your front knee stays aligned over your ankle and your back knee lowers towards the ground without touching it. Push through the heel of your front foot to return to the starting position. Immediately step forward with the opposite leg, repeating the same movement. Maintain an upright torso and controlled motion throughout the exercise.

Start in an athletic stance with your knees slightly bent and core engaged. Shuffle laterally for a set distance, then immediately stop and balance on one leg for a few seconds before continuing the movement in the opposite direction. Keep your weight centred and avoid excessive leaning while maintaining stability through your ankle, knee and hip.

Stand on a raised platform with one foot off the edge. Lower your unsupported hip downward, then lift it back up towards neutral using your glute medius. Maintain a stable torso and avoid excessive tilting.

Anchor a barbell in a landmine attachment or wedge it securely into a corner. Hold the end of the barbell with both hands or one hand (depending on the variation). Begin in an athletic stance with knees slightly bent. Explosively press the bar upward, extending your arms fully. Return to the starting position with control. Focus on power and speed during the press.

Stand facing a wall for balance, keeping your knees slightly bent. Push through your forefoot to raise your heels, maintaining a controlled movement. Lower back down slowly and repeat. Keep tension in the calves throughout.
Position yourself on a 45-degree back extension bench, crossing your arms over your chest. Lower under control, keeping a neutral spine, then extend back to parallel. Avoid overextending at the top.
Stand in a split stance, bouncing lightly on the balls of your feet, maintaining quick, reactive contacts. Keep posture upright and minimal ground contact time.

Sprint through evenly spaced hurdles or cones, focusing on short, quick strides with minimal ground contact time. Each step should be light and reactive, promoting efficient turnover and proper foot placement beneath the hips. The goal is to maintain a high sprint posture, active arm action and ankle stiffness, reinforcing an effective upright running position for max velocity sprinting. Avoid overstriding or allowing the foot to land too far in front of the body.
Stand with feet hip-width apart, then jump laterally from side to side, landing softly with minimal ground contact time. Keep your core engaged and use your arms for balance.

Lay on your back and hold on to a bench or static furniture with your arms above your head. Keeping your feet together, lift your entire lower body up into the air while keeping a firm core. Slowly lower back to the ground but without touching it (stay under tension).

Stand facing a wall with your hands pressed against it at shoulder height, leaning forward at an approximate 45-degree angle. Start with one knee lifted toward your chest and the other leg extended behind. Drive the rear leg forward while simultaneously bringing the opposite knee down, switching legs in one explosive motion while maintaining a rigid core and stable upper body. Quickly reset to the starting position and repeat the switch as fast as possible while maintaining proper mechanics. Focus on forceful knee drive, active foot placement under the hips and minimising ground contact time.

Anchor a resistance band low to a sturdy surface and loop the band around the front of your foot, just above the top of your toes. Sit on a bench or floor with your knee bent and your foot flat on the ground, ensuring the band pulls your foot backward towards the anchor point. Slowly flex your ankle forward, pulling your toes up toward your shin, then return to the starting position. Keep the motion controlled and your heel grounded throughout the movement.
